title: I Am Watching You
author: Driscoll, Teresa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On a train ride to London, a woman overhears two young men chatting up two teenage girls. They flirt for a while and soon the young men convince the gOn a train ride to London, a woman overhears two young men chatting up two teenage girls. They flirt for a while and soon the young men convince the girls that London will be more fun if the girls agree to join them at a club that evening. The woman eavesdropping on all this finds out the young men have just been released from prison. What to do? After gleaning all the necessary information to make a call and warn their parents, the woman agonizes over whether or not to meddle and ultimately does not make the call. The next morning, one of the girls from the train goes missing.Such is the premise of "I Am Watching You," a serviceable mystery, fast-paced, simply written, broken down into short chapters featuring various integral characters. The premise leads us down many interesting paths, there are lots of twists and turns, and the ending is one I didn't expect even though there were hints along the way. The book has a few flaws and moments that don't quite ring true, but these are excusable, because the story is quite good and clips along. A nice palate cleanser for anyone who wants a diversion from heavier fare....more

title: State of Wonder
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read three other Ann Patchett books ("The Patron Saint of Liars," "Run," and the award-winning "Bel Canto"), and I have loved all of them. TrulI have read three other Ann Patchett books ("The Patron Saint of Liars," "Run," and the award-winning "Bel Canto"), and I have loved all of them. Truly loved them. They were very different from each other- the settings, the themes, the tone, the pacing - and yet, I connected with all of them and often recall scenes and moments that still speak to me and move me. "State of Wonder," on the other hand, was so devoid of authenticity from start to finish that it felt like it wasn't even written by Patchett, and I am a little heartbroken to have to give it a bad . (There may be spoilers ahead.)The story centers around Marina, a middle-aged pharmacologist working for a large pharma company (and entwined in a secret relationship with the CEO) whose lab partner and friend is sent to the Amazon to track down the brilliant and headstrong elderly ethnobotanist, who is being generously funded for her research into a remarkable new drug, but has not been reporting back on her progress for months at a time. When the lab partner sent to track her down is subsequently reported to have died there, the CEO decides to send Marina to the Amazon to do what her friend could not. Do you see the problems with this scenario already? Why is an elderly ethnobotanist being left to her own devices for months, sometimes years, with virtually no contact whatsoever (she could be dead for all they know) by a pharma company who continues to foot the bill for all of her needs despite having no idea how far she has come in the drug development process? [Note: I have worked for big pharma - this would NEVER happen.] Why are two people wholly unequipped for difficult passage in the Amazon sent ALONE to scope out the situation? [Note: A wealthy pharma company would provide a team, a guide, a plan of some sort. A middle-aged sedentary lab doctor would not be the first choice for this mission.] And why would...Let me stop myself here. This was the problem with every sentence of "State of Wonder." Not a single scenario made any sense at all. Every plot contrivance was so ludicrous, in fact, that I started to wonder if this were not a straightforward narrative at all, but a set-up, and that I would discover somewhere in the middle of the book that this was some existential dream - the fever dream of a woman in the Amazon or a woman in an asylum or some sort of drug-induced delirium. I started to actually hope that it was, because that would have made the book far more interesting and believable. I won't go on. You see my issues here. I gave the book two stars, because despite it's ridiculousness, I kept reading, which is something I rarely do when contrivances bother me this much. I still wanted to see if something unexpected would redeem the story, some greater point would be made or some hint of genuine connection would surface to remind me of the writer whose books I have come to love over the years. Unfortunately, that did not happen. If you don't mind suspending disbelief over and over again, by all means, read this book. The prose is still captivating and the characters hold a weird mystique. But if you like a well-crafted, thoughtful book with genuine depth and enough realism to create a connection, try one of the other Patchett books mentioned above. They are far superior to this one and shine a better light on an author I otherwise highly recommend. ...more

title: Dead Mountain: The Untold True Story of the Dyatlov Pass Incident
author: Eichar, Donnie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My friends and I tasked ourselves with choosing "bucket list" items a while back. When my list turned out to be largely just a list of places to whichMy friends and I tasked ourselves with choosing "bucket list" items a while back. When my list turned out to be largely just a list of places to which I had not yet traveled, I was told to choose at least one thing I have always wanted to do, regardless how improbable it might seem. I've never wanted to jump out of an airplane or swim with sharks, but I'm just a big enough nerd that I have always wanted to solve a mystery - a cold case crime or a strange occurrence that many have puzzled over but no one has ever figured out conclusively. Donnie Eichar, the author of "Dead Mountain" appears to be a kindred soul in that respect. Upon hearing about the Dyatlov Pass Incident, a tragic mystery that involved the deaths of nine young Russian hikers in 1959, he became obsessed with the case, burying himself in research, contacting Russians with ties to the story, and depleting his own resources to make the trip to the Urals to retrace the steps of the ill-fated hikers. The mystery itself is fascinating, and when Eichar follows the timeline of 1959 and these fresh-faced college students, eager to conquer the challenge of a harsh terrain, unaware of the fate that would befall them, the tale is riveting. It is when he tries to flesh it out with the story of his own attempt to recreate those conditions that the writing occasionally bogs down, much the way a really good short story writer may turn out a middling novel just by overreaching.Here are the basic facts that make the Dyatlov Pass incident a mystery for the ages, causing almost everyone who has ever heard of it to ponder its many facets:1) Nine healthy, young, experienced hikers are all found dead in two separate groups and areas of the frozen Ural tundra after failing to return home on time.2) Their bodies are found only partially clad, none of them is wearing shoes or boots.3) Their tent is found in perfect order, boots lined up neatly, stove partially assembled, fully stocked with food, dinner having been prepared and eaten.4) The back wall of the tent appears to have been slashed open with a knife from the inside in order to allow panic-stricken hikers to exit.5) Strange orbs of light had been seen in the area that month by other hiking groups.6) Government testing was thought to be done in that region, some of it nuclear on occasion, and the clothing of the hikers is found to have higher than usual radiation.7) One hiker is found with her tongue missing and another with no eyes.8) Several hikers have apparent blunt force trauma, despite official cause of death for most, if not all, hikers being, ultimately, hypothermia.9) The area has other potential real or imagined threats, including a logging camp, a prison camp, a Mansi enclave, and the usual wild animals.Donnie Eichar does a nice job at the end of the book, by going down the list of every viable longstanding theory in this case and effectively debunking each one. His vast knowledge and research supported this rejection of accepted theories, and I found it very plausible. Like Sherlock Holmes, he had told himself that "when you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth." The problem being that once Eichar had eliminated what he believed to be the impossible, nothing was left. And here, maybe because he felt compelled to solve this mystery or maybe because his editor had told him he had better solve this mystery or the book would not be published, Eichar came up with a theory of his own. A theory that has some interesting science behind it and makes for yet another facet to this tragic riddle surrounding young lives lost. The author seems certain he has solved the mystery, but I came away just as convinced that this was not the answer. In the end, perhaps no one will ever solve the Dyatlov Pass Incident. For those who read the book and wonder why I may not be on board with the author's final conclusion, I point again to the boots that not even one experienced hiker chose to put on or even grab on the way out of the tent that night, knowing he or she was about to encounter sub-zero temps on a harsh, windy night. In addition, his theory rests on the idea that all parties responded similarly to the phenomenon detailed, an assumption I find outlandish. And ultimately, I find it interesting that no theories ever took into consideration human interaction or the possibility of turmoil or threat within the group. Regardless, for me, this mystery remains unsolved, although Eichar has laid out the details of the trip (and the many solid theories that survive to this day) very well in a book that is fascinating and a quick read. So, check it out. Maybe you will finally be the one to solve what really happened on Dead Mountain. I will most likely think about this tragic conundrum off and on forever, while I seek yet another mystery to solve....more

title: The Overstory
author: Powers, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "If you are holding a sapling in your hand when the Messiah arrives, first plant the sapling and then go out and greet the Messiah." - (Jewish saying)"If you are holding a sapling in your hand when the Messiah arrives, first plant the sapling and then go out and greet the Messiah." - (Jewish saying)"When is the best time to plant a tree? Twenty years ago." - (Chinese saying)In "The Overstory," Richard Powers has given the world a love story to nature, and even more specifically, to trees. But fear not, reader, this is not some extended Joyce Kilmer poem or Hallmark card to our dwindling natural world. It is a series of thought-provoking character studies - linked vignettes that take a hard, sometimes gritty, look at human interaction (with trees and with each other) - that offer a dire warning to the inhabitants of earth, as well as a plan of action for possible salvation. Powers makes a strong case for what should be the obvious fact that if those of us in the "understory" do not preserve the "overstory," only one of these will cease to exist, and it won't be the latter. The trees and the natural world have thousands, even millions, of years to rebound, (years they will need after we have decimated so much forest land), while we may have only scant years left to practice optimum conservation and save ourselves in the process.Powers is smart enough to know that facts and figures and a preachy didactic tome will never get his point across. He takes the advice of one of his own characters who declares, “The best arguments in the world won't change a person's mind. The only thing that can do that is a good story.” And a good story is what we get. In fact, we get a series of good stories, as Powers introduces us to nine main characters, many of whom will find that their lives intersect later on in the book. It's a clever device. One I was not sure was effective at first, because I did not know these separate, seemingly isolated stories would connect later on, but I came to appreciate this bit of craft as I moved deeper into the book and saw that the lives of our characters were made to mimic the lives of the trees, interconnected, communicating with each other, anticipating each other's needs, sometimes directly, and sometimes in subtle, unseen ways. The author knows we are vain, self-absorbed humans who need to focus on human needs or anthropomorphize the world around us, so he makes us care about nature and the need to protect the trees by making us care about a collection of people who care about the trees. He admits this ploy late in the book when a character tells us, "To be human is to mistake a satisfying story with a meaningful one, and to mistake life for something huge with two legs. No: life is mobilized on a vastly larger scale, and the world is failing precisely because no novel can make the contest for the world seem as compelling as the struggles between a few lost people."Among these "few lost people" in "The Overstory" we meet an artist with a tragic past, a jetsetting businesswoman, a young psychologist from a dysfunctional family, a married couple facing challenges, an injured soldier turned Johnny Appleseed, a brilliant computer game designer, a college coed who comes back from electrocution with a gift, and my favorite character in the book, the organic chemist Patricia Westerford, who gives us the important scientific component of this dire ecological equation, while also giving us one of the more emotionally compelling and tender stories in the book. Powers wants us to know that we are always going to be exposed to the stories other people tell and some stories may have more passion or be more enchanting or just feel truer, but unless they are backed up by science, they are just fiction, and we should know the difference. As a girl, Dr. Westerford learns to love nature and the language of trees from a kind, attentive father who explores botany with her in childhood experiments: "She hears him, and understands. This is science and worth a million times more than anything any person might ever swear to you."In addition to this scientific component, Powers introduces a powerful psychological component to our seeming inability to act on what should be an urgent issue. The fallacy that consensus is truth. This is introduced in the story of our military man turned forest savior: “In fact, it's Douggie's growing conviction that the greatest flaw of the species is its overwhelming tendency to mistake agreement for truth. Single biggest influence on what a body will or won't believe is what nearby bodies broadcast over the public band. Get three people in the room and they'll decide that the law of gravity is evil and should be rescinded because one of their uncles got shit-faced and fell off the roof.” And while this seems anecdotal, we later learn from our psychology professor that study after study confirms it. People act based on the beliefs of the crowd. Even if the crowd is very, very wrong.As a final example, I'll mention the story of the computer programmer, who builds a world more lush and plentiful than the world we know, a world that causes its players to sit huddled in basements for hours at a time trying to build a better version of their existence. While our own world is being torn down around us, the world of this game lures players with its endless paradise -until one savvy player complains that there is no point to it. There is no endgame. Players just amass more and more meaningless things to no avail. The programmer is forced to admit he has a Midas problem - "Everything's dying a gold-plated death." The name of the game: Mastery.I could write a  as long as the book itself, but that may be the greatest gift of "The Overstory," because despite the fact that it is a bit too long and sometimes confusing, and builds on many stories told by other authors in other books (Bill Bryson, for one, taught me about the chestnut trees long before Powers did), it is a book that forces you to think, and maybe even to act. For that alone, it may deserve a five star rating, because you may read other, more compelling stories about a few lost people in your lifetime, but few will make you contemplate what that lifetime means and whether or not your species should be the only star of that history.Lastly, I fully understand the irony of having read this book in a hardcover format (I think it would have been a brilliant move to make it only available in downloaded versions), but as Dr. Westerford tells us, “To solve the future, we must save the past. My simple rule of thumb, then, is this: when you cut down a tree, what you make from it should be at least as miraculous as what you cut down.” "The Overstory" has accomplished that feat, and then some....more

title: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous
author: Vuong, Ocean
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “They say nothing lasts forever, but they’re just scared it will last longer than they can love it.”In this achingly beautiful, disturbing, poignant, “They say nothing lasts forever, but they’re just scared it will last longer than they can love it.”In this achingly beautiful, disturbing, poignant, soul-crushing novel, Ocean Vuong weaves a poetic narrative built around the construct of a letter to his mother, a Vietnamese survivor of war, transplanted to Hartford, Connecticut with her son and mother. It is a letter he knows she will never read because she cannot speak or read English, and it is the only way he feels able to reveal the details of their story while she is still alive, a story full of nightmares, memories, confessions, and the many ways there are to feel displaced in the world. The son, called Little Dog, now a man in his late twenties, admits to his mother: “I only have the nerve to tell you…because the chance this letter finds you is slim – the very impossibility of your reading this is all that makes my telling it possible.”There is no way to adequately describe the impact of this novel in a ; you really just have to read it. Maybe it is because Ocean Vuong is a poet first, the imagery he conjures is both delicate and raw, but also potent and unexpected at every turn. He is able to juxtapose beauty and brutality in the lives of his characters and find a way to come to terms with both, often in prose that is somehow both lush and concise, gorgeous and sparse, a tightrope walk of paradoxy. He has managed, in a relatively short book, to capture the whole world. Family bonds, war, abuse, goodness, cruelty, race, class, sexual orientation, beauty, kindness, addiction, culture, grief, sex, love and loss – all of it. Literally all of it. And he does so with a fierce economy of language that makes the reader sit pondering the enormity of each sentence for a long time afterward.I could open the book to any page and quote any line and it would most likely be meaningful. All I can do is offer a selection of moments, as Vuong does, in a story that is really a series of snapshots, memories from his youth and the stories he has been told about the lives of others. I was often struck by his apt descriptions of the people he encountered:On his mother: “What do we mean when we say survivor? Maybe a survivor is the last one to come home, the final monarch that lands on a branch already weighted with ghosts.”On a customer who wanders into his mother’s salon: “About seventy, her hair white and windblown across a narrow face with mined-out blue eyes, she has the stare of someone who had gone beyond where she needed to go but kept walking anyway.”On his friend Trevor: “There was something about the way he looked when lost in thought, his brow pinched under squinted eyes, giving his boyish face the harsh, hurt expression of someone watching his favorite dog being put down too soon.”“It seemed the boy was always looking at a plane wrecking itself midair. That’s what I saw that first day. And although I knew that nothing behind me was on fire, I turned back anyway and saw the coiled summer air, sputtering with heat, rise over the razed fields.”“I did not know then what I know now: to be an American boy, and then an American boy with a gun, is to move from one end of a cage to another.”I was also taken with the way Vuong often used animal imagery to comment on human frailty:Discussing veal: “The children, the veal, they stand very still because tenderness depends on how little the world touches you. To stay tender, the weight of your life cannot lean on your bones.”Or making a startling acknowledgment about family while watching television with his colorful grandmother Lan: “We saw a herd of buffalo run, single file, off a cliff, a whole steaming row of them, thundering off the mountain in Technicolor. “Why they die themselves like that?” she asked, mouth open…They don’t mean to, Grandma. They’re just following their family. That’s all. They don’t know it’s a cliff.”There are some haunting scenes in the book that will linger in my mind, and some insightful observations that I will be mulling over forever. But mostly, I am grateful that Vuong has offered us this extraordinary work and this vulnerable young man named Little Dog who is bravely visiting those parts of himself that most of us tuck away and refuse to share. Mining the past can be scary business, but Vuong seems to be reminding us that when you dredge up memories and commit them to the page, your past becomes art and your artistic medium is one of pain but also of beauty....more

title: Clock Dance
author: Tyler, Anne*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “She had tried her best to be a good mother-which to her meant a predictable mother. She had promised herself that her children would never have to wo“She had tried her best to be a good mother-which to her meant a predictable mother. She had promised herself that her children would never have to worry what sort of mood she was in; they would never peek into her bedroom in the morning to see how their day was going to go. She was the only woman she knew whose prime objective was to be taken for granted.”This is how Willa Drake, the protagonist of Anne Tyler's novel "Clock Dance" sees herself in the world, as a placid, obliging, neutral force who never wants to cause a fuss. Tyler takes us through a few defining moments in Willa's life to let us know how she has come to be a 61-year old woman, unsatisfied with her life but unsure how to change it, yearning for some sort of purpose and usefulness. This is why we have a whirlwind of life changes and snapshots in time thrust at us in the beginning of the book in a few patchy chapters that catapult Willa from schoolgirl to senior in the blink of an eye with no real chance for us to truly get to know her family members or experience their lives in any meaningful way. We meet Willa in 1967, the eleven year-old daughter of a volatile, melodramatic mother (given to fits of abuse) and a mild-mannered obedient father too unassuming to confront her (a man "so mild-mannered that he thought it was impolite to pick up a telephone in mid-ring”). Willa assumes her lot in life is to be like one or the other, so she chooses the path of her father, the mediator, the practical calming influence, not fully realizing that this is also the path of the voiceless doormat, never speaking up, never taking any initiative. We see this even more clearly when the book jumps ahead to 1977, Willa's college years, and we meet her take-charge boyfriend, Derek, who is ready to graduate and has a high-powered job lined up in California. Willa has a year left and a coveted opportunity with her favorite professor to look forward to, but when Derek presses her to marry him that summer and then stands up to her aggressive mother, she chooses one difficult life partner for another and the years fly by. 1997, an unexpected life change occurs, and Willa is left to pick up the pieces and make choices that could change the course of her life entirely, but all too soon it is 2017, and Willa is the same unassuming woman, now married to a man who is just another version of Derek, living a life she never asked for but which she has obligingly settled into. “Sometimes Willa felt she’d spent half her life apologizing for some man’s behavior. More than half her life, actually. First Derek and then Peter, forever charging ahead while Willa trailed behind picking up the pieces and excusing and explaining.”Once we get to this point, though, the meat of the story really begins here, in 2017, when Willa receives an unexpected phone call and makes a rare snap decision to travel from her home in Arizona to Baltimore to help the former girlfriend of her son, Sean. Here, we are introduced to a rag-tag neighborhood of quirky, interesting characters all revolving around the home of Denise (the former girlfriend and recent shooting victim) and her daughter Cheryl (a precocious and endearing eleven year-old, who provides Willa the opportunity to feel like a grandmother for the first time in her life). The people we meet in Baltimore just pop off the page, and are so vividly described you can picture them as clearly as if you were watching a movie. Tyler's descriptions of each of them and their interactions with each other are the most engaging part of the story and her fondness for the shabbier suburbs of Baltimore found me almost rooting for Willa to abandon her upscale home in AZ to live in Denise's twin bed guest room for the rest of her life. Willa's immersion in this new cast of characters gives new life both to the character and the story, and her relationship with young Cheryl reminds her of the dreams she had as a girl. "She had felt that way during her own childhood; she’d felt like a watchful, wary adult housed in a little girl’s body. And yet nowadays, paradoxically, it often seemed to her that from behind her adult face a child about eleven years old was still gazing out at the world.”This is a book about determining for oneself what makes a life worth living. The way Willa and others in the book address this question makes us consider it as well, and may make some readers ask themselves whether or not change is even feasible - at any age or at any point in a life. Can someone on a steady path decide to upset the apple cart and set a new course, and is it worth the risk? Tyler has always dealt with this subject. Characters who find themselves in unexpected situations, desperate for change but also clinging to the security of the lives they know. "Clock Dance" isn't her best book. She tackled these subjects far more effectively in books like "The Accidental Tourist" and "Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant." The first few chapters of this book seem like an almost unnecessary slog to get to the far more engaging scenes in Baltimore. But maybe that's the point. Like Willa's, some lives seem like a bland slog through endless days of the same old thing unless you decide to shake things up a bit and consider a new uncertain road. So, I marginally recommend this book, especially to fans of Tyler, who will feel like they are revisiting an old friend and who will see some of her flashes of brilliance in the second half of the book. And after meeting the gang at Denise's neighborhood in Baltimore, you may feel, as I do now, that I ought to make an effort to talk to my neighbors more often....more

title: The World That We Knew
author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "If you do not believe in evil, you are doomed to live in a world you will never understand."With her trademark magical realism, Alice Hoffman deliver"If you do not believe in evil, you are doomed to live in a world you will never understand."With her trademark magical realism, Alice Hoffman delivers a haunting tale of the fate of the Jewish community living in France during WWII. Like every Hoffman novel, this one is part character study, part chronicle of a time and place, and part fairy tale - only in this story the fairy tale is darker than some others she has told, and we follow her characters into the woods like Hansel and Gretel, wondering who will survive and who will be lost forever. I am not going to offer a long synopsis of the plot. You can read that online and we all know the horrors and atrocities that befell the Jewish community and the Resistance fighters in the war. This, as well as other facets of the story, may make a reader apprehensive or unwilling to invest themselves in a tale they may feel they already know, especially when magic and religion are along for the ride. But I urge those readers who are unsure to take the plunge. In Hoffman stories, there is always some sort of magical element: a ghost, a tangible fate, an angel, a demon, signs and symbols, but somehow they are never unbelievable or figments born of the realm of fantasy. They are the everyday magic of ordinary people. Every person you know who has told you they have a ghost in the attic or get signs from their dead loved ones or believe an angel delivered them from harm. They are everyone we know. And ourselves. People who want to believe in something even when belief is hard to come by or impossible to support. This tale gives us a golem, a being born of clay that is foretold in the darkest lore of Jewish mysticism. Only a rabbi is supposed to be able to create this life, but our golem is created by his strong-willed daughter in a pact made with a desperate mother to find a protector to care for her daughter when she no longer can. The golem is usually made in the image of a man, but these women create a woman protector, whom they name Ava, reminiscent of "chava," the Hebrew word for life. The golem is brought to life with the word "emet" written on her arm, a word meaning "truth." Whether you want to believe in a golem or not, what is happening here is a parable of maternal love and protection, the strength of women to create life and to protect that life with all their might. The women characters in this novel prove to be fierce and protective warriors, in both love and spirit, independent thinkers who know they must depend upon themselves for salvation in a world turned upside down. This does not discount the male characters at all, a mostly sympathetic assortment of decent men trying to protect their families and survive in a France they no longer understand. Especially compelling is the story of young Julien, dutifully staying in Paris with his parents who are in denial about how unsafe it has become and how much danger they are in until the officers come to the door and march them away ("His father had put on his hat, as if he were going to a meeting and must look his best."). Julien's many brushes with fate throughout the story tear at the fabric of our understanding of why some people survive and others do not and seem to convey the idea that in a world that has become evil, good people cannot allow themselves to be lambs led to slaughter, believing that rules are made to keep them safe. They must do whatever is necessary to survive.The subject of religion comes up often, as it should in this context, and is handled in beautifully delicate exchanges that convey the ways religion can be a foundation for good deeds or twisted to become a weapon against others. In a telling exchange in the story between a Jewish grandfather and his Catholic granddaughter, he asks her to recite the Lord’s Prayer, which she does. He then recites for her a Jewish prayer, which is strikingly similar. “They have the same meaning,” she said to the old man. “Yes, they are the same, and a world apart. Say one and you are applauded. Say the other and you’re condemned.”Hoffman’s descriptions of nature, of a field of improbable silver roses or a majestic heron in love with a woman or a black wolf with yellow eyes who lets a child live, are among some of the most enchanting prose you will ever read. She has a way of reminding us that everything from the rosemary and lupines blooming in a garden to the wild wind in the branches of lime trees are so often the images that bring us joy and comfort, the images that make being human easier to bear, because the world is cruel but also beautiful.It is difficult to live in the world in 2019 and not see parallels of the treatment of Jews during the war to the treatment of other marginalized groups being demeaned and blamed for a country's ills today. People in camps having children separated from them, living in squalor without appropriate care or decent treatment. People being sent back to places where they are immediately killed. "The World That We Knew" speaks to what makes us human in a world that is so often filled with evil and cruelty and wrestles with the ways some humans ever decide to look upon other humans as lesser or undeserving of kindness. “This is what it was to be human, to be at the will of fate. This is what it felt like to lose a child you loved who had loved you in return…She was helpless against time, the owner of a fragile heart…This is what love did. It was a miracle and a sacrifice.”...more

title: The Testaments        (The Handmaid's Tale, #2)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “Once a story you’ve regarded as true has turned false, you begin suspecting all stories.”I read "The Handmaid's Tale" when I was young. At the time, “Once a story you’ve regarded as true has turned false, you begin suspecting all stories.”I read "The Handmaid's Tale" when I was young. At the time, I thought it was brilliant, well-written, and complete science fiction - something that was an important cautionary tale and certainly an homage to the many woman (and men, but mostly women) who fought bravely for equal rights in this country, but unthinkable in a country that had come so far on its trajectory toward more inclusive legislation. It was outlandish in the 1980's to think of a world where women were just property and vessels for children, devoid of any power over their own lives, subhuman in the eyes of male leaders. Not here in America. I read "The Handmaid's Tale" again recently, and thought "Oh my god. It's all happening. If this administration had its way, we would be living in Gilead, and this nation would be a corrupt theocracy, serving the desires of rich white men to the exclusion of all others, especially women."Suddenly, what I once thought science fiction has become terrifyingly real. "The Handmaid's Tale" was originally published in 1985. Thirty four years later comes its sequel, "The Testaments." Why thirty four years later? Look around you. In a world where Social Darwinism appears to have been a dream, and society does not seem to naturally progress toward a better, more egalitarian mindset, a sequel to "The Handmaid's Tale" is more necessary than ever. And who better to warn us of the dangers of a corrupt theocratic patriarchy than Margaret Atwood, a woman whose life's work has been a monument to social justice while still bringing us unforgettable characters in some of the finest prose in the English language. "The Testaments" does not focus on the Handmaids this time - oh, they're there, still toiling away, exploited little vessels of forced reproduction - but Atwood's focus this time is on three characters whose lives will intersect in surprising and powerful ways. There is Agnes, the young Commander's daughter being forced into a despicable marriage with a pedophile; Daisy, a Canadian girl who unknowingly harbors a dangerous secret, and the now elderly and infamous Aunt Lydia, who may be on a cunning and calculated path for redemption. Switching back and forth between these three narratives, Atwood gives us a glimpse of how a corrupt government might be subverted if just a few brave people are willing to risk themselves for the greater good. Of course, it really helps if at least one of those people also has a brilliant plan and some power to wield in this sacrificial strategy. And, as it turns out, one of them does. I won't get into too many spoilers here, and although you can read this novel as a standalone, it does help to have read "The Handmaid's Tale" first or some of the odd rituals of Gilead will make little sense to you, but I will say that this sequel is as compelling and forceful as the original, in my opinion, and is also brimming with something the first novel did not have - hope. As we have all seen in recent months, when the gears of a big political machine begin to work against the needs and aspirations of the very people who depend upon it, and corruption and cruelty seep into every facet of that system, the average person has little power to change the situation. Those in an ever-evolving totalitarian state are wrapped in a cocoon of helplessness, forced to accept the rules put in place by oligarchs who control all of the resources. Toppling such a regime when all of your rights have been taken away seems virtually impossible. Unless you have a network of resistance and a powerful ally or two. Such is the precarious position of Atwood's theocratic nation of Gilead since we first set eyes on it, now rotting from within, plagued by scarcity and decay, a haven for pedophiles and abusers given free reign due to "God's will," and a place of unrest as its citizens learn more of defections and life in neighboring free states.To read a synopsis of the political impact of Atwood's novels without having read the novels themselves might make less politically-minded readers shy away from them. That would be a pity. Atwood writes like a dream and her characters are vibrant, engaging people with depth and startling inner dialogues, whether they are mulling over their fates or undertaking perilous acts to save the world, despite their otherwise ordinary lives. (Atwood startlingly even makes us feel compassion for our former villain, Aunt Lydia, by giving us a horrifying glimpse of how she became who she is - a glimpse that asks us to consider whether we ourselves would have chosen a similar path in order to survive). Aunt Lydia tells us “Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, and I took the one most travelled by. It was littered with corpses, as such roads are. But as you will have noticed, my own corpse is not among them.” And later, she challenges us “How can I have behaved so badly, so cruelly, so stupidly? you will ask. You yourself would never have done such things! But you yourself will never have had to.” The power of "The Testaments" comes largely from our own understanding of what good people are sometimes forced to do in a world that will eliminate them for non-compliance. So, if you are worried about the state of the world and are concerned about disturbing trends toward the crumbling of democratic ideals and the quashing of human rights and values, you should be. And Margaret Atwood is, too. But unlike you, Margaret Atwood has a plan. Let's hope none of us ever needs one....more

title: The Lost Man
author: Harper, Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jane Harper comes through once again with a character-driven, atmospheric mystery set in the unrelenting heat of the Australian outback. This story, uJane Harper comes through once again with a character-driven, atmospheric mystery set in the unrelenting heat of the Australian outback. This story, unlike her two previous books featuring Aussie detective Aaron Falk, is a stand-alone novel about a cattle ranching family grappling with the mysterious death of a family member - a death that might be an accident, or possibly a suicide, but could even be murder, and if the death is somehow the latter, then it is an act that defies the unwritten rules of its locale: you never leave a man to die alone in the outback.Cameron Bright, middle brother to ranchers Nathan and Bub is found dead, literally baked to death, at the foot of a legendary landmark called The Stockman's Grave, a headstone in the middle of nowhere that has lent itself to various local ghost stories for decades. His fully stocked and functional vehicle is found a few miles away, and there is no sign of violence or trouble. Thus begins a twisted little tale that unfolds gradually, subtly, like a shadow winding its way around a headstone in the harsh Australian sun. For me, Harper's sparse but evocative writing lures me in from the first page, every single time. Her stories are always character-driven, and those characters are relatable, even if they are not always easy to like, as in the case of Lost Man protagonist, Nathan Bright and his brother Bub, both of whom are plagued with deep flaws, dark pasts and questionable behaviors. The dysfunctional Bright family history unwinds alongside the details of Cameron's unusual death, and Harper uses the interplay between current loss and youthful memories to fashion a timeline of inevitability - something bad was bound to happen - if not this death, then something else. This is also seen in the juxtaposition of Cameron's death and that of the legendary stockman - everyone in the area has a different version of what happened to the stockman, just as everyone is forming their own opinion of what might have happened to Cameron. Harper's use of the stark existence of people living in extremes of isolation and a brutal climate only heighten the reader's anxiety - "people were either completely fine, or very not." The landscape becomes another character, its influence so pervasive and influential. Harper's other books were five star gems for me, and this nearly received the same rating, but in the end, much as I adored the writing, the pacing, the flawed, authentic characters, the cunning revelations as they unfolded, and the all-encompassing feel of the remote desert setting, I had an issue with the final reveal that has been gnawing at me, and so I have ticked off the tiniest bit due to my own issues with its believability, (an issue very few other readers seem to have had, by the way, so take it with a grain of salt). But one thing I would like to point out is the exceptional job Harper does at handling issues like domestic abuse and sexual assault and human frailty in a way that is even-handed and realistic without once being exploitative or didactic. As it turns out, this book is really a book about hard choices. Each character in the book has a hard choice to make, a life-altering choice, in fact, each one different and of the utmost importance. And each choice is tied to this mysterious death that has affected them all. The fate of every character in "The Lost Man" can be summarized in one telling quote from the story itself, “Someone can decide it’s in their best interests to agree to something, but a choice is only really a choice if there’s a genuine alternative.”...more

title: Force of Nature        (Aaron Falk, #2)
author: Harper, Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I became smitten with Jane Harper after her debut mystery novel "The Dry," and her follow up novel did not disappoint. "Force of Nature" sees the retuI became smitten with Jane Harper after her debut mystery novel "The Dry," and her follow up novel did not disappoint. "Force of Nature" sees the return of Australian financial agent Aaron Falk, as he and his new partner tackle the disappearance of a prime witness in an ongoing money laundering investigation. A financial investigation might sound bland to some, but this one is different: our witness disappeared in the bushland while on a corporate team-building camping trip with a host of suspicious colleagues. Is the woman alive or dead? Was this an accident or foul play? Could a legendary bushland killer be involved? Could our witness have run away rather than turn over evidence? Harper juggles all of the possibilities and the many potential suspects in a perfectly layered mystery told in a riveting narrative mixed with intermittent flashbacks of the camping trip. Through it all, she never loses sight of our main character Falk, interspersing memories of his father into the current situation and analyzing the way his past has informed his present task at hand. (It is not necessary for a reader to have read "The Dry" prior to this novel, but it does help to understand certain references to Aaron and his past.)I am not a fast reader. I read this book in two sittings, staying up all night to do so. Harper writes with such a natural voice that the resulting book seems effortless, a style I find all the more remarkable in a mystery novel because, with Harper, you never see the craft behind the plot, there is never an obvious contrivance or an instance of taking the easy way out. If Jane Harper had 365 novels in print, I would have to quit my job for a year, because I would feel compelled to read one a day. That said, I hope she is writing a new Falk novel right now. ...more

title: The Dry        (Aaron Falk, #1)
author: Harper, Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was reading a mystery/thriller book recently, one that came highly recommended. Great s, lots of hype. I got a couple of chapters in, and I coI was reading a mystery/thriller book recently, one that came highly recommended. Great s, lots of hype. I got a couple of chapters in, and I couldn't keep going. The plot became unnaturally contrived, the players were stilted caricatures, and things started happening that defy both logic and statistics. So....I happened to have this Jane Harper book I had picked up somewhere....From page one, I heaved a sigh of relief. This book was already significantly better than the previous novel I had thrown to the side. Jane Harper has an easy way with language and can evoke a mood and a setting almost effortlessly. This novel is set in Australia during a long heat wave and drought. That setting is necessary to the storyline, but Harper doesn't beat you over the head with it. In fact, other than some reasonable local color, the book could be set almost anywhere that mirrored the necessary conditions. This is a story set in rural Australia, but isn't rife with mentions of kangaroo and vegemite. Harper knows better. She is taking the specific and making it universal.Aaron Falk is the protagonist of "The Dry," and apparently this is the first of other novels that will feature this likable police officer (specializing in financial crimes), but I didn't know that at the time. Nor did I need to. This book has no loose ends that need to be tied up in other books. It is whole and perfectly fashioned as is. Falk has returned to his hometown after many years away in order to attend the funeral of his childhood best friend. The death of his friend appears to be suicide (and there is much more to that element of the story that I will not give away here), but Falk agrees to investigate a bit for the sake of the man's parents, who were close to him throughout his early years. Falk has tremendous baggage as he returns to this place where he is notorious, because, as a teenager, he was accused of a close friend's death, a death that may or may not have been caused by him, or by someone else, (perhaps even his recently dead best friend) - or by the victim herself. Are the two deaths related? Are either of them what they seem to be? This is the premise our author sets up for the reader as she leads us deeper and deeper into a rural farm town, reeling from economic hardship, suffering through years of barren crops and insufferable heat, and simmering with secrets and lies. I am not a fast reader. I like to savor each word. But I flew through this book, only putting it down twice, and that reluctantly. Some authors, like the one whose name I will not reveal from the book I tried to read prior to this one, take a premise and try to fit it with unnatural elements and colorful characters, whether or not they have to cram those square pegs into the round holes of their outlines or not. Jane Harper, on the other hand, takes a compelling premise and lets it reveal itself naturally, like an inevitable unfolding, showing just a bit more of the truth with each new angle or revelation our characters encounter. To tell you more would spoil that unfolding. Discover this wonderful author for yourselves, the way I did and then look forward to knowing more about Aaron Falk in book two and beyond....more

title: The River
author: Heller, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love the way Peter Heller writes. His book "The Dog Stars" is among my favorites of all time, largely because Heller captures the poignancy of humanI love the way Peter Heller writes. His book "The Dog Stars" is among my favorites of all time, largely because Heller captures the poignancy of human survival in its pages and expounds on what constitutes a life worth living, while also showing us both the sweetness and ruthlessness of nature and humanity. In that regard, "The River" is very similar. This intimate tale of two friends on a camping trip in the deep woods of Canada gives us a glimpse of the best and worst life has to offer, both from human interactions and from nature in all its wild glory.Jack and Wynn have been friends since college, when they discovered that not only do they both have a love and aptitude for wilderness treks but also a love of literature and the arts, sculpture, music, mindfulness and philosophy. Their complementary natures seem to be the perfect fit and they share mutual admiration and respect for each other's abilities and sensibilities. We meet them on their way down the titular river in the midst of their last big trip before work and winter sideline them. This trip, however, is about to become far less idyllic as the duo pick up the scent of a giant wildfire mere days away and happen upon a few sketchy characters in their effort to put as much distance between themselves and danger as possible. First of all, if you have a love of the outdoors and an affinity for the woods or are enraptured by tales of mountain men or modern day Thoreaus, you absolutely have to read this book. Heller's descriptions of the wildlife and scenic landscapes the friends encounter along the way are visually stunning and his detailed descriptions of the camping/fishing life are sheer perfection. (If the outdoors interests you not at all, you may not find the prose nearly as enjoyable as I did, but I could have read page after page about this trip, even if no perils or plot points had intervened.) A good portion of the book is largely a character study, in which we get to know two people of substance, each with rich inner lives and interests, doing what they love most together.As is so often the case when everything is going smoothly and people put their guard down to bask in the pleasures of seeming synchronicity, life rudely intervenes. Our friends' leisurely nature trip becomes a harrowing experience in which they have to navigate (literally and figuratively) raging rapids, an unexpected wildfire, a rescue mission, and a possible murderer, as well as the murkier problem of assessing human intentions, perhaps the most dangerous element of all. There are those who see this as a straightforward adventure tale with the added heft of the fully formed characters involved. That may very well be all that it is, and if so, it is still a perfectly worthwhile, riveting little tale. But as someone given to over-analysis of pretty much everything, I feel Heller is offering us more than just "A River Runs Through It" meets "The River Wild." Heller has given us two characters, Jack and Wynn, who love literature, have deep thoughts, discuss philosophical concepts and delve into cultural belief systems. Heller himself is a product of the Iowa Writers Workshop. How many books have you read that have a river as their central metaphor? If you are a Goodreads reader, probably quite a few. So, it might be remiss not to see the river as the spooling out of a human life, dotted with the simple pleasures and the ensuing perils that constitute every life. Jack and Wynn seem very similar, until you are told that Jack is the realist, the pragmatist, an engineer with the soul of a scholar, who has a bit of a temper and is more likely to see the darker motives at work in the world. Wynn, on the other hand, is the gentle soul who wants to see the best in everyone, the sculptor with the heart of a poet, who forgives easily and makes art for art's sake. Their values are the same, but their responses to the world at large can be quite different. At one point, Wynn tells us about a favorite poem of his by W.S. Merwin:"Merwin describes the sun going down believing in nothing and how he hears the stream running after it "It has brought its flute it is a long way"...It killed him. The one and only sun without belief in anything and the little stream believing so hard, believing in music even." I don't think this poem was chosen at random. Jack and Wynn. The sun and the stream. So, without too many spoilers, I will just say that Heller seems to be asking us with each new danger and each new choice our protagonists must face, "How should we approach the world, with skepticism or with altruism? Is it ever acceptable to break with our core values, even if it means we may not survive? Are we foolish to aspire to values that others may not even hold? Does living a life of integrity and optimism make us vulnerable or evolved - or both?" Early in the book one of our characters mentions that Thoreau used to do his laundry at Emerson's house. It seemed like a throwaway line at the time, but I think it was intended to illustrate that even those, like Thoreau, who spurned most human interaction and the trappings of modern life still had to break down and join civilization and its social mores every once in awhile, whether he wanted to or not. I think in this excellent tale of two men reveling in nature until nature fails to cooperate, Heller shows us that idealism is an excellent concept, until it isn't....more

title: Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland
author: Keefe, Patrick Radden
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If you are Irish, the Troubles have become a part of your common tribal understanding, much like the potato famine or the legend of St. Patrick, but yIf you are Irish, the Troubles have become a part of your common tribal understanding, much like the potato famine or the legend of St. Patrick, but you don't have to be Irish to be fascinated with the history of this turbulent time, especially because it is a recent history and one with reverberations that are still felt to this day. Before this extraordinary book, much of our understanding of this time remained hidden, concealed within the walls of so many Belfast flats, secrets kept close to the vest out of fear, guilt, or protection from others. IRA members, especially Provos (members of what is known as the Provisional IRA, a breakaway faction dedicated to violent means) were sworn to secrecy, and those with loose lips traditionally ended up dead on a sidewalk or "disappeared." So how did Keefe manage to write a book that not only utilizes exhaustive research and modern interviews, but is filled to the brim with intimate details of the lives of IRA members, their organizational structure, their crimes, their sacrifices, their loyalty and betrayals, often verbatim from the members themselves? Oddly enough, the answer is Boston College.In 1998, after thousands of casualties and decades of The Troubles (centuries, depending upon your interpretation, but decades if you trace the organized fighting to the modern IRA), Northern Ireland and the UK agreed to the terms of the Good Friday Agreement (Irish people are very big on Good Friday, I can tell you from experience. In my own family lore, my Irish great grandfather is said to have willed himself to die on Good Friday, weeks later than his doctor gave him). The GF Agreement was, in essence, a long-awaited ceasefire and hope for the future brokered in large part by Gerry Adams, controversial president of Sinn Féin, the IRA’s political wing, and a member of the British Parliament (more about him to come). That is when some researchers at Boston College decided to compile a series of oral histories of IRA members and other key figures of the Troubles that would be kept secret and not released until after their deaths. Some of the most notorious of the IRA's Provos were persuaded to sit for hours of interviews and divulge information they had never previously discussed, even with their families or each other. The readers of "Say Nothing" are the beneficiaries of that knowledge, because thanks to a lack of legal protections (and a host of British subpoenas) much of this treasure trove of intimate knowledge was released early, and Keefe crafted it into an amazing book that reads like a murder mystery. In 1972, widowed mother of ten Jean McConville, was taken from her apartment in Belfast by masked intruders, in front of her children, and never seen again. Keefe sets out to unravel this mystery and the fate of McConville while giving us a history of the provisional IRA and its very colorful cast of characters. We meet the Price sisters, Dolours and Marian, who were indoctrinated into a world of violence through family history and through the violence inflicted upon them for their Catholic faith, and who became two of the most dangerous IRA members as well as the popular face of the organization. We meet Brendan Hughes, the high ranking IRA mastermind, brash and fearless, who later feels left behind as the politics become more of a priority than the struggle. And, among others, we meet Gerry Adams, the suave sociopath, who rose to a place of prominence in Irish politics, but clearly also directed the Provos in murder and bombings and all manner of IRA missions, although he denies any involvement to this day, (even though Keefe makes clear in the book that McConville's "disappearing" was most likely on his orders). Keefe deftly navigates the story of the IRA, the British military, and the victims of both sides, while allowing us to feel both horror and sympathy, fascination and disgust. He also briefly touches on the misplaced pride sometimes felt by Irish-Americans for the IRA, a phenomenon I have seen myself, having been raised Irish-American in a mostly Irish-American town in Massachusetts, where old timers often hinted that one of my relatives was a "runner" for the IRA as a teen. It is said with a twinkle in their eye, but has always left me cold as I learned the violent history of that era and the many tragic stories it has spawned. By telling us the tales of actual characters on both sides of the Troubles and by delving into their lives, often through their own words, Keefe has brought to life this time period in a way no other book I know has ever accomplished....more

title: Jane Eyre
author: Brontë, Charlotte
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: *spoiler alertFor a book that has been around since before my ancestors fled the potato famine, and which has been dissected for over a century by sch*spoiler alertFor a book that has been around since before my ancestors fled the potato famine, and which has been dissected for over a century by scholarly minds far superior to my own, I find I have a lot to say about this book, having just embarrassingly read it for the first time (hey, every now and then you miss a classic – I wanted to rectify that situation). My first observation is - Charlotte Bronte is a wonder! And every observation beyond that is pretty much the same. Having read “Wuthering Heights” years ago, I assumed this book might have a similar bent and the same soul-shredding themes of lost love and tortured existence, but although young Jane certainly goes through her share of cruel circumstances and difficult challenges, (and is given to as many long walks on the windswept moors as Catherine Earnshaw was), there is an optimism and brightness of tone that Charlotte infuses into her work that is absent in that of her sister Emily. There is also a kindness of spirit and sense of practical resolve not found in the former work. One is a Gothic tale of passionate but cruel obsession, the other a surprisingly feminist take on the triumph of an independent mind and the rewards of living a decent life. On first meeting the ten-year-old Jane, an orphan begrudgingly taken in by a rich aunt and abused by her spoiled cousins, we find her a marvel of resilience and will as she suffers one unkindness after another only to somehow maintain her self-esteem. When her aunt, Mrs. Reed, unjustly commands that she not be allowed near her cousins, Jane blurts out, “They are not fit to associate with me!” and our love affair with the character has begun. When sent to Lowood, a strict boarding school characterized by ascetic conditions and near starvation of the pupils, Jane finds a beloved friend in Helen Burns, a bright, accomplished child who is even more emotionally abused than Jane, but who suffers in silence believing the cruelty is deserved and designed to make her better. Jane tells Helen what she thinks of that approach when she says, “…you are good to those who are good to you. It is all I ever desire to be. If people were always kind and obedient to those who are cruel and unjust, the wicked people would have it all their own way; they would never feel afraid, and so they would never alter, but would grow worse and worse. When we are struck at without a reason, we should strike back again very hard; I am sure we should - so hard as to teach the person who struck us never to do it again.” Quite the bold statement for a little girl in the 1800s! And this novel is populated with dozens more instances of Jane’s independent thinking and bold resilience. Bronte makes much of Jane’s plain appearance, letting us know this is a woman who will not be pursued by avid suitors attracted by her loveliness. She also lets us know that Jane is not a frivolous person desiring a husband to care for her. She wishes to remain an independent woman, with or without a future husband. For an era when making a suitable match was more often an economic necessity for a woman and a form of legal slavery for a man, this struck me as a radical mindset, and one that surely would have shocked polite society of the day. It is also no doubt a reason this book has survived and remained popular for more than a century and a half. That, and the fact that Bronte writes like a dream. Her descriptions are vivid, her dialogue snappy and well-paced, her inner thoughts a delight to know, and her depiction of even the most tragic events made more startlingly real by their honest rendering and lack of melodrama. It is as if Bronte is saying, through Jane, “This is life. You deal with it and pick yourself up again and move along or you cease to be of use to the world.”Her relationships with both Rochester, and later St. John Rivers, are both fascinating and troublesome at the same time. As for Rochester, he’s an unforgettable character and one I could both praise and condemn in an equal number of pages. Since the existence of books, I doubt any publisher has wanted for stories of proud, manipulative, brash cads who need only meet their perfect match in life to reclaim their inner goodness and be “tamed.” It is the familiar trope that has ensnared generations of women into believing that cruel men can become good if only loved well. Domestic shelters are currently filled with women who have bought into this recurring mindset. But in Rochester’s defense, I will say that he is not bewitched by frivolity or superficial charms but by depth of character and self-awareness, and he supposedly falls for Jane due to her equality of spirit and frank nature, which is perhaps why we are able to somehow tolerate his many atrocities against her throughout the book, ones that she bears more easily than we do, as he plays with her affections, tests her resolve, and hides a really nasty secret in the attic. (For a feminist take and interesting historical perspective on poor Bertha Mason, check out the far more recent prequel “Wide Sargasso Sea” by Jean Rhys. Rhys says what I would like to say about the treatment of this character far more effectively than I could.)When forced to leave Rochester (by her own sense of integrity), Jane suffers some true hardship in her ill-planned escape from Thornfield. Penniless, unconnected, starving, the description of her reduction to drifter and beggar - and her eventual salvation - is some of the best prose you will ever read. That said, the coincidences that occur in this portion of the book are among its weakest elements. That she would happen upon just this remote home in just this part of the country with just these inhabitants and be needed for just the perfect job at hand and discover that just the exact person who…well, if you’ve read the book, you know the rest, and if you haven’t, I won’t spoil it, but as much as I still loved the story and its new characters and the twists and turns it took, I also said in the back of my mind, “Oh Charlotte, come on, even you can’t be buying this part.” Still, if only to highlight the nature of Jane’s relationship with St. John, these later chapters made for a strong and fitting contrast between that dynamic and the relationship between Jane and Rochester, in that it illuminated her resolve to approach even romance on her own terms. She, a woman with few prospects and little beauty, could have made an excellent match (by society’s standards) with a man respected and handsome, (who had saved her life and given her employment and a home), but she could not allow it of herself because she refused to marry a man who did not love her, who viewed her as a workhorse of noble character, a practical partner, an employee with benefits. Heady stuff, for its day, considering that rejecting such a proposal might be the source of economic hardship for most women - and might never come again.The resolution of the story, I admit, will bother me forever. Largely because it delighted me as much as it disgusted me. There is no way this amazing, strong-willed, independent force of nature should waste her youth shackled to a crabby old wreck of a man, consumed by insecurities and jealousies, and more in need of a nursemaid than a wife. But dammit, by the end of the book, I want this for her as much as she seems to want it for herself. I know in my heart it’s a terrible match, but it’s the match she wants, it is what makes her happy, and even in real life, what looks good on paper doesn’t always work. So, we revel in Jane’s terrible choice, and wish her joy and feel relieved when Rochester seems to have made himself worthy of her by the book’s end. “No woman was ever nearer to her mate than I am: ever more absolutely bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh. I know no weariness of my Edward's society: he knows none of mine, any more than we each do the pulsation of the heart that beats in our separate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together.” So, if Jane is happy, we are happy. Reader, I forgave him....more

title: The Overstory
author: Powers, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "If you are holding a sapling in your hand when the Messiah arrives, first plant the sapling and then go out and greet the Messiah." - (Jewish saying)"If you are holding a sapling in your hand when the Messiah arrives, first plant the sapling and then go out and greet the Messiah." - (Jewish saying)"When is the best time to plant a tree? Twenty years ago." - (Chinese saying)In "The Overstory," Richard Powers has given the world a love story to nature, and even more specifically, to trees. But fear not, reader, this is not some extended Joyce Kilmer poem or Hallmark card to our dwindling natural world. It is a series of thought-provoking character studies - linked vignettes that take a hard, sometimes gritty, look at human interaction (with trees and with each other) - that offer a dire warning to the inhabitants of earth, as well as a plan of action for possible salvation. Powers makes a strong case for what should be the obvious fact that if those of us in the "understory" do not preserve the "overstory," only one of these will cease to exist, and it won't be the latter. The trees and the natural world have thousands, even millions, of years to rebound, (years they will need after we have decimated so much forest land), while we may have only scant years left to practice optimum conservation and save ourselves in the process.Powers is smart enough to know that facts and figures and a preachy didactic tome will never get his point across. He takes the advice of one of his own characters who declares, “The best arguments in the world won't change a person's mind. The only thing that can do that is a good story.” And a good story is what we get. In fact, we get a series of good stories, as Powers introduces us to nine main characters, many of whom will find that their lives intersect later on in the book. It's a clever device. One I was not sure was effective at first, because I did not know these separate, seemingly isolated stories would connect later on, but I came to appreciate this bit of craft as I moved deeper into the book and saw that the lives of our characters were made to mimic the lives of the trees, interconnected, communicating with each other, anticipating each other's needs, sometimes directly, and sometimes in subtle, unseen ways. The author knows we are vain, self-absorbed humans who need to focus on human needs or anthropomorphize the world around us, so he makes us care about nature and the need to protect the trees by making us care about a collection of people who care about the trees. He admits this ploy late in the book when a character tells us, "To be human is to mistake a satisfying story with a meaningful one, and to mistake life for something huge with two legs. No: life is mobilized on a vastly larger scale, and the world is failing precisely because no novel can make the contest for the world seem as compelling as the struggles between a few lost people."Among these "few lost people" in "The Overstory" we meet an artist with a tragic past, a jetsetting businesswoman, a young psychologist from a dysfunctional family, a married couple facing challenges, an injured soldier turned Johnny Appleseed, a brilliant computer game designer, a college coed who comes back from electrocution with a gift, and my favorite character in the book, the organic chemist Patricia Westerford, who gives us the important scientific component of this dire ecological equation, while also giving us one of the more emotionally compelling and tender stories in the book. Powers wants us to know that we are always going to be exposed to the stories other people tell and some stories may have more passion or be more enchanting or just feel truer, but unless they are backed up by science, they are just fiction, and we should know the difference. As a girl, Dr. Westerford learns to love nature and the language of trees from a kind, attentive father who explores botany with her in childhood experiments: "She hears him, and understands. This is science and worth a million times more than anything any person might ever swear to you."In addition to this scientific component, Powers introduces a powerful psychological component to our seeming inability to act on what should be an urgent issue. The fallacy that consensus is truth. This is introduced in the story of our military man turned forest savior: “In fact, it's Douggie's growing conviction that the greatest flaw of the species is its overwhelming tendency to mistake agreement for truth. Single biggest influence on what a body will or won't believe is what nearby bodies broadcast over the public band. Get three people in the room and they'll decide that the law of gravity is evil and should be rescinded because one of their uncles got shit-faced and fell off the roof.” And while this seems anecdotal, we later learn from our psychology professor that study after study confirms it. People act based on the beliefs of the crowd. Even if the crowd is very, very wrong.As a final example, I'll mention the story of the computer programmer, who builds a world more lush and plentiful than the world we know, a world that causes its players to sit huddled in basements for hours at a time trying to build a better version of their existence. While our own world is being torn down around us, the world of this game lures players with its endless paradise -until one savvy player complains that there is no point to it. There is no endgame. Players just amass more and more meaningless things to no avail. The programmer is forced to admit he has a Midas problem - "Everything's dying a gold-plated death." The name of the game: Mastery.I could write a  as long as the book itself, but that may be the greatest gift of "The Overstory," because despite the fact that it is a bit too long and sometimes confusing, and builds on many stories told by other authors in other books (Bill Bryson, for one, taught me about the chestnut trees long before Powers did), it is a book that forces you to think, and maybe even to act. For that alone, it may deserve a five star rating, because you may read other, more compelling stories about a few lost people in your lifetime, but few will make you contemplate what that lifetime means and whether or not your species should be the only star of that history.Lastly, I fully understand the irony of having read this book in a hardcover format (I think it would have been a brilliant move to make it only available in downloaded versions), but as Dr. Westerford tells us, “To solve the future, we must save the past. My simple rule of thumb, then, is this: when you cut down a tree, what you make from it should be at least as miraculous as what you cut down.” "The Overstory" has accomplished that feat, and then some....more
