title: So Long, See You Tomorrow
author: Maxwell, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: “What we, or at any rate what I, refer to confidently as memory--meaning a moment, a scene, a fact that has been subjected to a fixative and thereby r“What we, or at any rate what I, refer to confidently as memory--meaning a moment, a scene, a fact that has been subjected to a fixative and thereby rescued from oblivion--is really a form of storytelling that goes on continually in the mind and often changes with the telling." William Maxwell's spare, near-perfect prose is the retelling of just such a memory, a memory from childhood that still haunts the now-elderly narrator, the way regrets from one's childhood, seen through the lens of adulthood, can follow one forever and never lead to a satisfactory resolution. Maxwell transports the reader to 1920's Illinois, and a scandal that rocked the sleepy farming community there, changing forever the lives of the families involved and severing the bond between two young friends impacted by the events. The narrator is one of those young boys, now old, looking back on the era and the murder that took his young friend away from him. The power of this book is in its ability to paint a picture of the class structure of the Midwest, the domestic structure of that system, the inner lives of two farming families, and the sad spiral of events that lead to infidelity, broken homes and murder - all while at its heart being the story of two young boys and the simple joys of childhood they shared before the world collapsed beneath them. The book itself is short, nearly a novella, and its colloquial feel and simply stated observations work to great effect here. Like the heartland it purports to chronicle, the language mirrors the characters and the times, but also stuns with its honesty and wisdom, while never shying away from the difficult themes it addresses.The narrator makes clear his regret for a small indiscretion now writ large across his past, a slight against his friend Cletus that was meant as a kindness, but in hindsight is seen as a devastating mistake (“I had inadvertently walked through a door that I shouldn’t have gone through and couldn’t get back to the place I hadn’t meant to leave.”), but we find that each character in the story harbors regrets, some far greater than those of the narrator, who generously observes the foibles of his characters and concludes "so often people have no choice." We witness how one series of events can be experienced and rationalized and justified in so many different ways by the various participants and observers, yet we must come to our own conclusions about guilt and choice while Maxwell never lets us lose sight of the crux of it all - the loss - the loss of innocence, the loss of hope, the loss of friends and family, the loss of the small familiar routines that make life "happy.There is not an unnecessary word or description in the book, but there are two sequences that stick with me the most. One takes place early in the book, when the narrator and his friend Cletus are playing on the beams of an unfinished home renovation. They are enjoying the excitement and camaraderie of the setting without a thought that one false move could change the world forever, their homes beset by unfinished business and unseen dangers. The second scene is near the end of the book when young Cletus is going through an ordinary day, and we see all the small joys that are about to be taken away from him - the windy walk home through farm country, the rusty bike, the fur of the dog he loves, the stone pot on the stove, the warm bread - and, perhaps even more than the shocking events that will succeed this vignette, this poignant description is the truly heartbreaking one. A young unsuspecting life about to be upended.  Maxwell's writing is a joy to read, but also makes one wistful in that it dredges up both the sweet specificity of past joys and the small regrets that never go away. In the end, the narrator sums up the longing and regret of the past by simply observing, "Between the way things used to be and the way they were now was a void that couldn't be crossed."...more

title: The Finkler Question
author: Jacobson, Howard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: So, Howard Jacobson was sitting down one night thinking that he would like to write a book about what it means to be Jewish in modern society. But howSo, Howard Jacobson was sitting down one night thinking that he would like to write a book about what it means to be Jewish in modern society. But how could he do it in the form of a novel? Well, he could create characters that represent different aspects of the Jewish experience. One could be an affluent Jewish scholar, a philosopher and writer whose viewpoints are highly regarded and whose books are even popular with the masses. Another could be an elderly man, the seat of Jewish heritage and culture, representing religious ideals and the crush of history. And yet another could be a Gentile who is friends with the other two men and who desperately wants to belong to their “clique,” who wants to know from an outsider’s perspective what it would feel like to be a Jew. The three of them could have vastly different relationships to the issues affecting the global Jewish community, and they could debate these issues over a series of dinners and meetings together. There, all the ancient and modern history could be examined, all the stereotypes exposed, all the atrocities digested, and all the labels acknowledged. It wasn’t a bad idea. It also helps that Jacobson writes fluid prose that is often very clever, and occasionally, laugh out loud funny. He also has a pretty decent grasp of sadness. He can write passages that examine the faithless progression of the dying, the utter loneliness of widowerhood, the lifeless void at the center of adultery, and the emotionless interactions of family members who don’t really like each other. Mr. Jacobson definitely knows how to put together an effective sentence. And I think that may be the only reason I was able to finish the book. The writing is superb. The story, less so. Julian Treslove, the main character of the book, is about as wishy-washy, uncommitted to anything and listless a character as you may ever encounter in a novel. His ability to be chameleon to any endeavor that piques his interest is Zelig-like. He has left his job at the BBC to become a celebrity lookalike hired out to parties. No one is sure which celebrity he is supposed to look like, but he looks like all things to all people, so it hardly matters. His life changes when he is mugged on the street by a woman, who he believes calls him a Jew while she is mugging him. This leads him through a life-altering phase within which he decides he really is a Jew and undertakes to fully become one. He gives up the waifish, bird-boned WASPs he so often dates, and takes up with a substantial Jewish woman named Hephzibah. Hephzibah is possibly the only likable, grounded, decent person in the whole book, so naturally we know Julian will most likely find a way to f*** up this relationship. No matter. If only this relationship, or any of the relationships in the book, had mattered as much to Julian – or to Howard Jacobson – as they did to the reader, this would have been a compelling story. What is it then, if not a compelling story? To be honest, I found it to be an ongoing diatribe about the plight of the Jew in modern society, whichis fine but not what I signed on for. Had it been couched in the elements of a decent plot, rather than using characters to represent ideological paradigms, I would have accepted the premise and come to my own conclusions, but there are issues even with the diatribe, once you accept that that’s what it is and stop waiting for the story to happen. Because the story never does actually happen. The paradigms just sort of run their course. As a non-Jew reading the book, I often felt my reactions or understanding of the issues may have been lacking. I am sensitive to the plight of any persecuted group, Jewish or otherwise. I watch the news – I have a basic understanding of the issues in Gaza, of Zionism, of neo-Nazism, of the Holocaust-deniers, of modern prejudice in all its forms. Jacobson thinks not. He means to educate me about my lack of knowledge in these areas, and I appreciate it, but he both makes and contradicts his point in the process. He asserts, and possibly rightly so, that everyone should understand, and be passionate about, these issues affecting the Jewish community - and then basically follows up with the notion...but you have to be Jewish to really understand it. Always a catch. Which is something Julian also struggles with while trying to fit into his adopted Jewish culture. He never quite gets it right. He isn’t clever enough, doesn’t have the Jews’ natural comedic timing and delivery when making jokes, doesn’t have the Jewish inherent knowledge of music, finance, theater production. Ah yes, another issue I had with the novel. Jacobson gets to use all the stereotypes. I’m sure he’s doing it consciously, but should he? Doesn’t he both make and contradict another point by doing so? And what’s more, if a non-Jewish person had written this book, can you imagine the fall-out? The only times Jacobson takes a break from his all-Jewish extravaganza is when he is busy being misogynistic. Like so many highly acclaimed male writers, Jacobson has issues with women. Big ones. They are whores, they are shrews, they are mothers or needy birds. The ones men are married to force them to seek out others to sleep with, because it’s just what men do, right? How dare they speak their minds? We’ll show them who’s boss with a little sexual submission. Ah, Norman Mailer, you are not forgotten. Next to Hephzibah, the two main female characters in the book are dead. It is so much easier for the men they left to care for them now that they are dead. The men have the heft of their loss to endear them to other women, and the revisionist memories that make them better husbands than they actually were. A dead wife is so useful. Despite all of this, and miraculously, I actually really like the way Jacobson writes. If he had taken his themes and even his agenda and utilized them in a well-constructed story where something actually happens and the characters are real people as opposed to conceptual vessels, I would have found the reading a delight as opposed to a pretentious romp through purely intellectual terrain. These characters could have mattered to me as much as the concepts did. And they could have mattered to a wider audience, as well, which is what Jacobson might have ironically missed in his need to educate rather than illuminate. ...more

title: Crooked Letter, Crooked Letter
author: Franklin, Tom*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I met "Crooked Letter, Crooked Letter" on a busy Saturday at Barnes & Noble. I was wandering about, being jostled by weekend shoppers who pushed past I met "Crooked Letter, Crooked Letter" on a busy Saturday at Barnes & Noble. I was wandering about, being jostled by weekend shoppers who pushed past me to pluck bright new bestsellers from shiny displays, when a blast of air from the door and a new wave of customers pressed against me, sweeping me back into the belly of the store, where I hastily sought shelter in a nook of the fiction section devoted to mysteries. Tired, disheveled, uninspired by any of the formulaic-looking new arrivals or cynical-sounding memoirs, I looked around aimlessly for a reason to stay. And there it was, silently dominating an end kiosk. It beckoned to me with its dark yet attractive cover art, its mysterious title, its inexorable pull. Shyly, I sidled up to it, exchanged a few meaningful glances, boldly fingered the edges. It seemed so unlike the other offerings, a little reserved, maybe, but also a little dangerous. There was just something different about this one. I suppose the rest is an old story: a few scattered phrases, an impulsive decision, and my new infatuation and I left the store together, headed for my place. For awhile the cover was enough, just looking at that darkly beautiful facade filled me with anticipation. And when I finally started in, tentatively pulling apart those first pages, getting a taste of this unexpected new style, I was drawn in, too curious and easily led. I was pretty sure I liked it. Pretty sure. No, maybe it wasn’t love, but that could come in time, couldn’t it? So I threw caution to the wind and dove in, headfirst. Too fast. I know that now. And “Crooked Letter, Crooked Letter,” sensing I was committing too soon, decided to slow things down. Way down. Instead of moving things along, CL spent long days telling me things I didn’t need to know in tediously minute detail. He conjured up random memories that would show him in an unattractive light, as if to dissuade me from falling for him. Sometimes he would play on my sympathies, bringing me back to him, wrapped in my protectiveness for the injustices of which he spoke, brimming with compassion for the misfits treated cruelly by the world, the people he knew, the people whose stories he shared with me. But often I was just frustrated with his idleness, his acceptance of memories so fraught with miscarriage and ignorance. Why don’t the people he writes about just tell the truth, stick up for themselves, push back a little, grow a conscience? And then he would let me know that things are different in that part of the world, where he comes from, the part of Mississippi where things don’t change and people don’t, either. And I would come back, briefly captivated by vivid pictures of the South and the slower pace of its inhabitants. We went on that way for awhile, dancing around the issue. I would spend a little time with him every other night or so and it wasn’t unpleasant, but it also wasn’t exciting. I often initiated contact begrudgingly, out of obligation, only to find that parting later was still difficult. I guess I wanted to love CL more than I did, wanted to find the promise of that first meeting, and never quite got there. Eventually, even his dialogue started to sound unnatural, a little exaggerated, a little derivative, as if he were saying what he thought he should, instead of what he really meant. I wasn’t born yesterday; I knew he was just feeding me a line. Hadn’t Stephen King used the same conversation in one of his books? Hadn’t Harlan Ellison said something similar in a story? I knew he was just imitating at times, I knew he didn’t mean it. So it ended, the two of us drifting apart, a pat ending that I saw coming a mile away. There were no surprises. No true revelations. I don’t regret the time I spent with CL. His story was interesting enough and some of it I will always remember. He didn’t live up to the hype, but we parted amicably with no harm done. Now it’s on to the next dark stranger. ...more

title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet’s Nest        (Millennium, #3)
author: Larsson, Stieg
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has been my experience that when an author writes a series of books containing the same basic set of characters, then that series tends to have a cIt has been my experience that when an author writes a series of books containing the same basic set of characters, then that series tends to have a certain consistency (in mood, plotline, style) that deviates very little from book to book. Crime and mystery novels, in particular, rarely deviate from the formula, and even the best of these contain an expected format, something the reader climbs into willingly, like a familiar old sweater. Well, Larsson obviously didn't get the memo. Or he got it and totally disregarded it, which I find both odd and strangely gratifying. Book One (Dragon Tattoo) was a unique and intricate murder mystery wound around a missing persons case and a separate financial scandal. It was haunting and desolate and full of unexpected twists and turns. Book Two (Played with Fire) was a fast-moving action thriller, a real cops-and-bad-guys story with beat-downs and shoot 'em ups and a good deal of suspension of disbelief. Book Three (Hornet's Nest) is unlike either of these. It is a sophisticated spy thriller ending in a classic courtroom drama, populated along the way with media intrigue and political overtones. There are fans of the series who wanted a more action-packed end to the saga and have bemoaned the fact that this third story seemed to be "all talk." While I understand the criticism and completely sympathize with the desire for things to go "out with a bang," be assured the story doesn't go "out with a whimper" either. And the "all talk" is pretty riveting talk at that - the tale of a super-secret division within Sweden's spy organization that operated outside the boundaries of its mother organization and was embroiled in all sorts of Cold War espionage. Not your average parlor talk. Add to that two subplots involving computer crime and hacking and a nice lead-up of evidence compilation to simulataneously utilize in the public arena and in the private courtroom drama, and you have a satisfying end to the series, one that gives you a sense of what lies ahead for the main characters, particularly our beloved Lisbeth Salander. Admuittedly, I am a self-confessed nerd who loves the paper trail and the research, the psychology and the analysis of a situation as much as the action, so a plot based in thought and verbal cues doesn't bother me at all. But at its heart, this is really a story about injustice and persecution. The fate of one small heroine rests upon the seemingly impossible task of defeating wealthy, powerful men in high places and entire organizations bent on self-serving interests. [And please tell me Teleborian is not the most sinister twist in a suit since Thomas Harris's Dr. Frederick Chilton in "The Silence of the Lambs."] So, anyone who loves a story in which the reluctant heroes cleverly outwit the powers who persecute the powerless, a story that exacts just revenge on those who would try to intimidate the innocent, or a story that exposes misogyny and injustice in our society and tackles it with thoughtful plot devices, will find this final installment a fitting end to Larsson's literary tour de force. ...more

title: A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First of all, Bill Bryson is a phenomenal writer. If you haven't read even one of his books, you really ought to do so right away. Secondly, "A Walk iFirst of all, Bill Bryson is a phenomenal writer. If you haven't read even one of his books, you really ought to do so right away. Secondly, "A Walk in the Woods" is probably his best known book, and rightly so, because it is a small gem of a book, detailing Bryson's attempt to walk the length of the Appalachian Trail with his comically overwhelmed friend, Katz. These two men, who have very little knowledge of serious hiking between them, and are really prime candidates for death by heart attack, sunstroke, wild animals, starvation or hypothermia, unimaginably decide to take on "the granddaddy of all hiking trails" for the sake of a Bryson book deal. As you can imagine, the two men find themselves in all kinds of taxing predicaments from the moment they set foot on the trail in Georgia until they reconnect with it later in the wilds of Maine, somehow managing to survive each new ordeal while subsisting almost entirely on boiled noodles and candy bars. The antics of Katz alone are well worth the price of admission; the man is a real character and Bryson's musings on him are filled with the wry, avuncular charm and humor we have come to know from his many books. In fact, three quarters of the way through the book, when Katz is no longer a part of the story for a short while, the narrative really suffers from his omission. His energy, equal parts surliness and likable nihilism, have really engaged the reader by then, and I, for one, was very happy to see him return near the book's final chapters. But beyond just the day to day travelogue of two men - who start off as bumbling incompetents and learn to become skilled hikers - this book is captivating for several other reasons, as it explores the (often troubling) history of the Appalachian Trail itself, its staggering array of botanical and animal species, and the hikers themselves who feel compelled to master this arduous journey of over 2000 miles. Bryson's true nature is that of an insatiably curious traveler, someone who not only takes a walk, but researches that walk and tells you all the details that led to it and all the things that might be spotted along the way, without ever making it feel as though you are on the other end of a dry, didactic lecture. Bryson is teaching a course on the Appalachian Trail in these pages and making you think he is just having a conversation with you, that you are just another friend hiking the trail along with him and Katz. "Let me tell you a little bit about that salamander over there." And "Did you know about the vast chestnut trees that used to dominate this trail and are now all gone?" It's like taking a camping trip with your favorite uncle. Moreover, Bryson also takes a little time to consider the mindset of those who thru-hike (hike the complete trail from one end to the other), and to delve just a bit into the nature of compulsion. I admit that is what often fascinates me the most about nature books and accounts of adventurers and explorers and outdoor enthusiasts. It is why I am fascinated with books like "Into the Wild" or "Into Thin Air" or the film "Grizzly Man." What makes people feel compelled to hike for hundreds of miles over terrain that changes little from day to day? Or climb the highest mountain, planning the next climb on the way down from the last? Or camp and live among wild, often dangerous creatures, knowing full well you may end up a meal for them someday? In my own past, I had a brush with the outdoor life. I spent a number of years with a wildlife biologist who was one of those real mountain men, the kind of person who could go up into the woods with a few necessities in his pack and come down a month later, none the worse for wear. As someone who had previously thought of camping as something you did at the beach, in an RV, on a concrete slab, I was more surprised than anyone to discover that off-trail hiking in the mountains and forests of the Southwest was something for which I seemed to have a natural ability. I was good at it. And it was intoxicating to know. It bred a kind of addiction for the outdoor life, a desire to see the hidden parts of the earth that few others ever come upon. But it also made me keenly aware of the dangers of that type of existence, the knowledge that you are only ever one bad fall or deep cut or mountain lion away from possible death. My memories of all those rugged camping trips and stunning hikes alternate between a great sense of wonder and accomplishment and a heightened appreciation of soft sheets, homecooked meals, and warm bubble baths. Bryson, too, during his journey, alternated between a kind of addiction for the hiking life and a desire for the safety and comfort of the mundane world. It was clear that given the time and inclination, he might have become one of those obsessive thru-hikers who cannot seem to stop hiking these trails, much the way Forrest Gump felt compelled to run or triathletes feel compelled to train. It is not really a love of the process. Many thru-hikers admit to hating it. But they can't seem to stop. Something inside them pushes them on. And I think that is what makes this book so appealing, even to those readers who may have little interest in the Appalachian Trail or the endangered species along its path or the historical figures who came to build the trail in the first place. Readers who have no experience with long hikes or rugged camping or curiosity for the wonders of nature. We all have a little compulsion in us, a little voice that urges us to try what may be unlike us or attempt things with which we are clearly uncomfortable. And some of us heed those voices and succumb to the pull of uncertainty and some of us do not. But among those who do are the clique of like-minded hikers who wake at the crack of dawn every day to a voice that says, "Go on, just a few more miles, just a few more miles until tomorrow..."...more

title: The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet
author: Mitchell, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The vast majority of my Goodreads friends are gaga over David Mitchell. Based on their high recommendations and constant urging, I chose to begin my fThe vast majority of my Goodreads friends are gaga over David Mitchell. Based on their high recommendations and constant urging, I chose to begin my foray into Mitchelldom with the most recent in his already impressive body of work, “The Thousand Autumns of Jacob De Zoet,” the tale of a Dutch clerk serving a trading post on a Japanese island at the turn of the century (the nineteenth century, as most of the book takes place in 1800). I was immediately struck by Mitchell’s amazing attention to detail. It was obvious that he had done exhaustive and meticulous research into the era – its history, its geography, its linguistics, its customs and mores and prejudices and precedents. From the possessions of his characters to the clothes they wore, Mitchell did not miss a beat, evoking a time and a setting as clearly in the reader’s mind as if it were something Mitchell himself had observed only yesterday. The characters he introduced us to were also a colorful bunch – a Dutch crew laden with pompous windbags, lowlife swindlers, backbiters, ruffians, and outright criminals – and then, conversely, a Japanese society of strict hierarchies, intense formalities, and a congress of leaders and interpreters who must often negate their feelings in order to accommodate social expectation. Add in an eccentric Dutch doctor with radically liberal philosophies and a penchant for cultural relativity, a fascinating Japanese midwife from an exalted family who dreams of being a doctor, and a Dutch clerk unmoved by the greed of his compatriots and determined to follow his Christian principles, and Mitchell seems to have laid the foundation for a compelling story. So, imagine how worried and befuddled I was when nearly 200 pages into the book I still did not find the story all that compelling. How was this possible? What on earth was I going to tell all of those Goodreads friends who love this guy? How could they ever believe or respect another of my s if I ended up disliking a book by this exalted demigod of the bookstore circuit? My street cred was on the line, and Mitchell was not helping me at all. After 200 pages out of 479, one doesn’t generally expect things to change radically. Usually you get that far into a novel and you can expect 279 more pages of what you started with. Boy, was I wrong about that. Suddenly, after all that investment of time and set-up, the story absolutely exploded. And I mean that in a good way. A brilliant way, really. It turns out Mitchell had meticulously laid all this groundwork expecting us to patiently follow him into this world he was constructing, counting on us to trust him, and then he let loose with a storyline I never saw coming (a plotline involving intrigue and pure evil related to nuns held captive in a mountain monastery)and then another that quickly followed it (related to a British naval frigate that shows up unexpectedly and causes sheer havoc) – and finally, finally, I understood the staggering genius at the core of his writing style. And make no mistake, this guy can write. He can do ornate and poetic descriptions as well as he can do the vulgar slang of sailors in conversation. His observations of beauty always hold a modicum of ugliness and his observations of evil always hold a modicum of hopefulness. He’s that kind of writer. The kind that never leaves you with a false sense of security because he tells you right away that any sense of security is ludicrous in a world so fraught with both expected and unexpected peril. Mitchell is also well aware that the themes that concerned people in the 1800’s are often the same themes that consume us today. Through his characters and their international trade pursuits, Mitchell gives us insights into the little-changed reality that greed is both a powerful motivator and a demonic cancer, that the meeting of two cultures often results in the arrogant ethnocentrism of inhabitants of both, and that often those people in possession of the greatest amount of talent and strength of character are the ones subjugated to the fringes of their environments while the well-connected or merciless thrive. And yet, even admitting such, Mitchell makes a case for the importance of integrity, the steadfast adherence to good will, and a belief that there is wrong and right – good and evil – in the world, and a person should follow rightness, regardless of the consequences. When you read this book and see the types of consequences facing our characters and the difficulties in remaining stalwart in such scenarios, you realize that Mitchell’s stance is not merely a platitude, but an admission of the brave and often brutal force of will required to remain good in the world. And does goodness lead to rewards and happy endings? Very rarely. As is so often the case in real life. In the end, Mitchell believes that a life is defined as much by one’s character as by the many regrets that haunt one’s memories, the tragic or wistful reveries of “what might have been.” No one gets exactly what he or she wants in life; no one is ever as truly happy as is possible. The things we could have said, the stands we might have taken, the unrequited love or the gold left unpursued – these lost possibilities are the things that define us even more than the things that we ultimately achieve.(Note: My four rating is actually a four and a half – and the only reason I subtracted from the rating is because of the many, many pages of set-up before the story took off and the quality Mitchell sometimes has of including unnecessarily gross or vulgar images in his writing merely for the shock value or repulsive quality of the image. I also feel he occasionally beats us over the head with symbolism. But he takes risks that other writers do not – often with unique and fiercely poignant results, and his research is impeccably integrated into the story as a whole. Mitchell is a force to be reckoned with.)...more

title: Game Change: Obama and the Clintons, McCain and Palin, and the Race of a Lifetime
author: Heilemann, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I generally have little interest in reading about the machinations of American politics. I realize this is a flaw, but I admit to it anyway. NonetheleI generally have little interest in reading about the machinations of American politics. I realize this is a flaw, but I admit to it anyway. Nonetheless, after the crushing lethargy brought on by two terms of the Bush presidency, I watched the last presidential race with a newfound interest. Who is Barack Obama underneath the idyllic visage? Is he really as good as he seems? Can Hillary Clinton overcome the negativity of her White House image to win this race? Is that doddering old McCain going to pull off a miracle or make a fool out of himself? Who in the hell is Sarah Palin? All of these questions and more caught my interest and made me pay attention to what seemed a crossroads in American history. This election was going to define our culture in some way. It was in the air. It was palpable. "Game Change" captures the electricity surrounding the campaigns of these famous entities (and their lesser rivals) by creating fascinating character studies borne out by meticulous research and hundreds of corroborating interviews. It is brilliantly written to have a "day in the life" feel to it, while still touching upon enlightening insights into the candidates' mindsets and rich nuggets of political maneuvering. Granted, it had a headstart on cornering the "interesting" market by already focusing on some of the most complex and riveting people in modern politics (Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton, Bill Clinton, John McCain, John Edwards, Rudy Giuliani, Sarah Palin, Joe Lieberman) - all well-known and iconic (and often, polarizing) figures in many ways. The initial battle for the Democratic nomination took up the lion's share of the book and for good reason. It was loaded with defining moments and featured one of the closest and most historic rivalries ever witnessed. The journey Obama and Clinton took together changed both of them, taught them some things about themselves, and made their new partnership also seem destined to be, despite its many contentious moments. Following them both along this journey was like being a fly on the wall and being able to overhear some of the most brilliant strategizing in a modern campaign setting as well as some of the most unexpected gaffes. Gaffes, however, were the stock in trade of the GOP campaigns in the last election, as this book shows in shocking, and occasionally amusing, detail. McCain banked everything on the unelectability of his rivals and was therefore able to ride one of the most financially bankrupt and poorly planned campaigns in history to a successful nomination. Spontaneous and hotheaded, McCain had his moments, but was saddled with the endorsement of a hugely unpopular president and a campaign team that was shoddily put together and slapdash in its approach. I was stunned to learn that Palin had only been vetted for a week before being sprung upon the RNC. McCain had hoped to run with Leiberman until his own team member leaked it to the press and set off an outraged explosion in the Republican party a couple of weeks before the planned announcement. Having to start again at Square One so deep in the race, Palin was chosen hastily, vetted poorly, and later deeply regretted as a choice, due to her obvious lack of knowledge about the issues, strange psychological behavior on the campaign trail, and tendency toward compulsive lying. (Biden's loose lips and occasional flubs paled in comparison, or could have been much more of an issue in a more traditional race.)Obama clearly comes off the best in this tome, largely because he truly seems to be the real deal, a guy who believes his own rhetoric, truly wants to change the world for the better, constantly educates himself about the issues and surrounds himself with competent advisors, and who adores his family. Some occasional arrogance and perhaps a little too much loyalty to old friends seems to be his only real flaw. Hillary, though far more complex and flawed, came off as quite sympathetic to me throughout the book. Her knowledge, her ability to charm and make alliances, her tolerance of her husband's antics, her desire to be liked - it all made her seem both noble and tragic at times. John Edwards comes off as a truly deluded man with a messiah complex who does not understand until far too late that he has caused his own ruin. McCain comes off as a man who had the ideals but not the temperament for the job - as someone who felt pressured to enter a race for which he was not prepared because of some idea that he needed to "save the party" (and that it might be his last chance at his age to run). His old-fashioned notions in the wake of Obama's youth-infused message of change made for a sad juxtaposition. Palin, frankly, comes off as a loon. A dangerous loon. And in fact, a loon whose platform is so far right even the right is embarrassed by it (signing off on legislation, for instance, to require rape victims to have to pay for their own rape kits). Nice. But the behind-the-scenes look at her and how overwhelmed she was by being tossed into the arena completely unprepared by McCain's team and then abandoned when she proved to be too much of a liability was an eye-opening feature of the race.Finally, there are the little nuggets in this book that are priceless. Hillary's clueless tirade when she finds out Obama's campaign has raked in a fortune selling T-shirts and other gear emblazoned with the candidate's face and message ("Why aren't we doing that?"), McCain and his cronies breaking up the tension of the campaign by endlessly viewing (and going into hysterical laughter over) the YouTube video of John Edwards primping his hair for an event, Obama mockingly adopting Palin's "You betcha!" at team meetings, or Palin refusing to study the issues for her upcoming Katie Couric interview while interrupting her handler with questions like, "What's Katie like?" and "How is my makeup?" (As you'll recall the Couric interview was a train wreck of immense proportions for the Republican ticket.)The race was endlessly fascinating for those who cared, and this book brings it all back in glorious detail. Now that we see Obama entrenched in partisan wars he had hoped to abolish and health care reform that took every ounce of energy and political compromising possible, it would be interesting to know if Obama's ideals are still intact, assaulted as they have been by the political machine. Hillary's place in history has been affirmed by her excellent work ethic as Secretary of State, Biden's mouth still betrays him, and Michelle has risen from a place of being misunderstood to being beloved. The "Game Change" this book details might very well have saved this country, though its citizens seem to have made that a dim memory at this point, but, however you view this election's place in history, its players remain endlessly fascinating. ...more

title: An Experiment in Love
author: Mantel, Hilary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The three star rating is no reflection on the writing or the material. Mantel is a brilliant novelist, the kind who can convey a great deal with spareThe three star rating is no reflection on the writing or the material. Mantel is a brilliant novelist, the kind who can convey a great deal with spare dialogue and a cleverly observed detail. It's just that I read her "Wolf Hall" first, and that book is such a masterpiece, that this intimate story seems a small book in comparison. It is almost as if a very good short story or novella had been expanded to fill the pagination requirements of a novel. The book concerns a group of female students in a wry "coming of age" tale set in 1960's London. Mantel is very good at setting the tone, and at letting you envision these people as true flesh and blood entities. You can see them as clearly as the people in your own hazy memories of youth. Their desires, their fears, the coping mechanisms they use to deal with their emerging womanhood - it all rings true. I definitely know these young women, have met them, have been to college with some of them, have shared some of their helplessness and some of their appetites. That it all happens decades before my own college experience does not date it, the same situations are still valid today. The inner life of the main character, Carmel, is beautifully rendered, we think her thoughts with her, we realize the strange empowerment of her self-sabotage, we understand the miscalculations of her sisters in the dormitory through her eyes, the woman she is hoping to be and the one she is hoping not to become. It's just that this is a story that feels familiar, as if other authors have tackled it before and possibly more effectively. It is a worthwhile read and a thoughtful study, but I cannot help but wonder, if Mantel had it to write over again, if she would lead us further into these lives, give us a richer world to enter and perhaps, follow into the future a bit more - or alternatively, if she would crop this a bit to find the very moving short story it would have made. ...more

review: Love her or hate her, Kathy Griffin makes no apologies for who she is. She is as candid when describing her triumphs as she is when describing the harLove her or hate her, Kathy Griffin makes no apologies for who she is. She is as candid when describing her triumphs as she is when describing the hard times and heartaches she has handled along the way. Already a fan, this book gave me new insights into the machinations of Hollywood and its players, as well as a new respect for this woman who rolled with the punches and finally found a way to successfully market her unique persona and talent. As fearless as Andy Kaufman, but with a work ethic that would impress the toughest CEO, a foundation in family values that would stifle the many groups who rail against her, and a sweet side that even she might not want to admit, Kathy Griffin made me laugh out loud on many occasions, gasp at her honesty on other occasions, and come away from this book wishing I could spend just one day hanging around with her. ...more

title: The Road
author: McCarthy, Cormac
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Where does one begin? Here we have a story about Earth in the aftermath of an apocalyptic event, a horrific and unsafe world of gray rivers and burnt Where does one begin? Here we have a story about Earth in the aftermath of an apocalyptic event, a horrific and unsafe world of gray rivers and burnt forests where people are few, but the majority of those few left alive have formed marauding bands of cruel and inhumane scavengers who most likely consider other survivors a source of meat rather than a source of companionship. Enter our two characters, Papa and the boy, traveling "the road" to reach the coast in hope of a better world there. They have devised a way of hiding and rummaging that has so far ensured their safety. They need to survive because they are "carrying the fire." So what is the road and what is the fire and why must the boy survive? The road is life, the life thrust upon them, the trudge from birth to death, the central metaphor, the river, this mortal coil. And the fire seems to be the hope of goodness, the idea that kindness is sacred, that love transcends. The boy embodies that sense of right in his altruistic dedication to other human beings, his earnest desire to help the others they encounter. The Papa is a world-weary realist, unsure that a happy ending can be had, but urged on by love, his love of the boy, who might be his son or who might be your son or who might very well be God. Mccarthy never tells us for sure, but he certainly lets us know that whatever God may be for some, to him it is the ability to love another human being. The scenes of man's inhumanity to man turn up at regular intervals in the book. Even in a world that has not experienced a nuclear winter or whatever catastrophe the earth is enduring in the book, we know enough of human nature to know that evil can rear its ugly head even in the best of circumstances, at any time, in any place, with or without warning. McCarthy's road is a place of ever-present fear and vigilance, a place where one false move can mean that you never take another step. This book, as a microcosm of the world, shows us throughout its pages the many ways a person can die. One is the victim of nature, struck by lightning. Others are shown to have died quickly in the catastrophic event, still in motion, pain stretching across fearful faces. Still others wither away from starvation or illness. Bodies litter this world. Then, there are those killed by the survivors, their bones boiled, babies roasted, still more captives kept in the dank holes of deathcamps until they can be killed for food. At one point McCarthy invokes the famous anthropological quote about "nature red in tooth and claw" when he muses about men white in tooth and eye. Are we little more than a mass of survival instincts when left in a world that requires it? Do we revert to primitive lobes in meager brains and care little for the others in our tribe? The case is made, although Papa and the boy are the exceptions, two people in that world who define their roles as "the good guys" and preserve as a goal the hope that they may never need to harm others. All through the book we pray that there are other exceptions to the inhumanity, other people alive who cherish goodness, because if there are not, then there is surely no hope - not for Papa and the boy, and not for us as a species. And death the eradicator waits at their heels. Our heels.This incredible little book deals with some huge themes, maybe the only themes. Who inherently are we? What does it all mean? And possibly even more heart-wrenching than thoughts of what it all might mean is the all-encompassing idea of "What does it matter?" When we lie in bed at night on the nights when we allow ourselves to contemplate mortality, these are the fears we hold and the answers we never get. McCarthy gives us an unflinching look at every angle, every possible pain and sorrow humans can endure. But through it all he also shows us the redemption of love, the meaning it holds for characters, a papa and a boy who could be any of our acquaintance, who could have pasted onto their faces the faces of our own father or husband or lover, our own son or nephew or neighbor, the people we love. And in the end, in even a cruel world where those alive have little else, even if nothing else matters, maybe love still does. ...more

title: Let the Great World Spin
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Life is full of unexpected synchronicities. The kinds of things that occasionally make you feel that you are connected to a greater web of being, a liLife is full of unexpected synchronicities. The kinds of things that occasionally make you feel that you are connected to a greater web of being, a little sign to let you know that you are not in this alone. Two days before I picked up Colum McCann's extraordinary novel "Let The Great World Spin," I watched the equally extraordinary documentary "Man on Wire" for the second time. Philippe Petit, more angel than human, strung a cable across the Twin Towers in 1974 and performed on it for over half an hour, walking, reclining, and literally dancing for the tiny human specks below and for the gods above (who could see him better, after all). It is a breathtaking sight, a man who has become art, who has made of himself something otherworldly and glorious. Like walking into a forest and seeing a unicorn or looking at the seashore and spotting a mermaid on a rock. It is therefore no wonder that the thread that ties together the vignettes in "Let the Great World Spin" is Petit's momentous tightrope walk as witnessed by the various residents of New York City. McCann introduces us to a number of these residents, some living gritty lives in the projects, others living lives of quiet luxury in a Park Avenue penthouse, still others trying to survive somewhere between the two extremes, in addresses less prone to preconception. And all of these residents are tied to the story and tied to the events of the day in ways that are sometimes obvious but more often as tenuous as a wire strung between buildings. But a wire that stretches. And holds. McCann's brilliance lies in the fact that each individual we meet is a revelation, a wholly expressed and vivid entity burnt onto our brain cells for all time. When we first meet the young Irish monk, Corrigan, living in a pit in the projects in order to try to protect the downtrodden, the hookers, and the elderly of the neighborhood, we jump into his world without a thought for our own safety, because we are smitten by his desire to bring goodness to bad places. As it turns out, he - and we - should have considered our safety a bit more carefully. So we learn straight off that some stories are not connected by so much as common addresses or economic status as they are by loss, by grief, by people left behind to trudge on when another's goals are left unfulfilled. Other characters will learn similar lessons, some by choice and others by circumstance, but McCann does not leave us behind like onlookers in a theater. He tells us these stories to make us look at our own and to consider the effect our lives have on the lives around us. Add to this ingenious structure the most perfect prose in modern literature and you have not a book, not a work of fiction, but an experience. McCann's stories are startlingly beautiful in many ways - their description, their construct, their gorgeous dissection of the dreams and memories of their characters. But the windows McCann opens, the doors he peers through, are just as often opening onto heartbreak as they are onto joy. Somehow, though, the grief and loss make the small tribulations and unexpected beauty that much more meaningful, the way a small remembrance can give us an inner photograph of our own unique definition of happiness. "So much depends upon the red wheelbarrow...", after all. McCann's characters allow us a glimpse of their sorrow and their happiness and let us decide if a balance has been achieved. That is, if the living of a life matters in the world, which is what McCann ultimately appears to be weighing in his fiction. Which is why he has allowed us glimpses into lives connected to other lives, and connected to other lives still, like the branches of an ever-expanding tree limb. How does this new person have an impact on the soul I have just become acquainted with, how can this person across town make a mark on the life of the one I just met in the Bronx? Late in the book one of our characters says, "It had never occurred to me before but everything in New York is built upon another thing, nothing is entirely by itself, each thing as strange as the last, and connected." Reading "Let the Great World Spin" makes me understand anew that we are all connected, that what we do matters, that our actions send ripples into the world that can affect other people in strange and unexpected ways. And every so often something stunning and remarkable happens that can bind us all together in sorrow or in joy. Like two planes hitting the Twin Towers. Or an angel walking between them. ...more

title: A Single Man
author: Isherwood, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Have you ever wanted to be a fly on the wall and observe a day in the life of someone you know or perhaps someone you barely know? Maybe there's a cowHave you ever wanted to be a fly on the wall and observe a day in the life of someone you know or perhaps someone you barely know? Maybe there's a coworker or a teacher or a barista at Starbuck's - anyone at all - that you wonder about. Do they live alone or have eight kids? Do they throw their socks on the floor or use a hamper? Are they gay or straight? What is a day like for this person? What does he or she think about? Christopher Isherwood understands that "fly on the wall" mentality and satisfies it brilliantly with his portrait of George, an aging professor and British transplant in California, whose partner has recently passed away. Isherwood gives us a day in the life of George, a day which might have been mundane or uneventful were it not for George's rich inner life and refreshingly frank observations. The brilliance of this little book is that George engages the reader right away. He is brutally frank, unflinchingly self-aware, and both flawed and endearing in equal parts. Whether he is having a pang of grief on the stairs (which he likens to a physical rather than emotional occurrence, comparing it to an "attack of cramp") as he thinks about the many mornings spent with his partner Jim, or disgusting himself by trying to win over the neighbor children who hate him by offering them a bag of candy, or frankly assessing his many physical flaws at the gym while trying to decide if his abs are too saggy to go shirtless, George himself might be surprised to find out that he is a reluctant everyman, thinking the same thoughts many of us have had, filled with the same misgivings and the same small comforts. Despite the fact that George is a gay man living in the 1960's, with all of the prejudices and consequences of that lifestyle during a time far less tolerant than today, his reactions to the pervasive public opinion are sometimes fair and sometimes equally prejudiced. And sometimes his anger spills over into almost laughably mental images of atrocities perpetrated on his verbal and political assailants. Isherwood knows that George is not perfect. He loves him for that reason and lets us do the same. In fact, the one time the book gives us an inner thought of another character, pure and not previously filtered through or perceived by George, is when we are told that George's neighbor, Mrs. Strunk, who George thinks secretly judges him and reviles his lifestyle, actually thinks to herself "he has a kind face." The book is at its best when George is just thinking his thoughts and giving us his interpretation of the world around him. Somehow, in his naturally engaging manner he drops real bombshells about the realities of grief, loneliness, aging, death, sexual desire, and the nature of friendship, while never becoming preachy, maudlin or sentimental. It is a book that becomes very poignant and moving, seemingly without trying to do so. I very nearly gave the book five stars, and almost wonder if I did not merely because of the book's apparent effortlessnesss, as if Isherwood could have jotted it all down in an afternoon. Any book that so brilliantly hides its craft within the folds of almost tangible characterization is a real accomplishment, and I am quite sure I will think about George for a very long time. ...more

title: Evidence of the Afterlife: The Science of Near-Death Experiences
author: Long, Jeffrey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The subject matter of this book is undoubtedly fascinating. A radiation oncologist with a scientific background comes across some textbook cases of neThe subject matter of this book is undoubtedly fascinating. A radiation oncologist with a scientific background comes across some textbook cases of near death experiences in medical journals early in his career and makes it his life-long mission to collect as many near-death experiences as possible from around the world and study their similarities and statistical consistencies, as well as their apparent occurrence in the face of medical improbability, to conclude that his body of work proves the existence of an afterlife. There are only two problems with the book that I can find: 1) Dr. Long is passionate about his mission and arduous about his methods, but cannot write an interesting sentence to save his life, and 2) Dr. Long points out nine lines of evidence to prove the existence of an afterlife, none of which actually proves the existence of an afterlife. So, why read this book? Because mortality sucks and despite himself Dr. Long has compiled the most extensive data in the field, some of it so amazingly similar in style and content that it defies being coincidental in nature or even culturally ingrained. When people make things up, they tend to embellish in ways that are inconsistent, adding details that do not maintain certain repetitive elements and constant stylistic devices. Reading a selection of the hundreds of thousands of entries Dr. Long has gathered makes it challenging to remain completely skeptical about the process. Dr. Long also brings up some interesting medical facts that make even science geeks and nonbelievers like myself think long and hard about our views on the nature of death and dying. Could it all be neurological, physiological, remnants of electrical currents in the brain? I've always assumed so. Dr. Long, however, offers some clear medical reasoning as to why that type of dismissive thinking is medically unsound. I have some major issues with many of Dr. Long's research methods, statistical values, and conclusions (the man is not afraid of big leaps), but the near death experiences themselves are the draw of this book, and wedged between Long's dry, clinical sentences and clipped conclusions, the voices of those who have briefly died, and yet lived to tell about it, make the pages briefly come alive. The amazing similarities in these hundreds of stories truly affected my perceptions of the event itself. Even if you don't come away from this book with a belief in any type of afterlife (guilty as charged), it is still difficult to walk away from this book without the strangely comforting feeling that the moment of death may not be a cause for terror but rather the experience of a pleasant journey to a place where love and peacefulness reign supreme. Beyond that, one must come to his or her own conclusions about eternity. ...more

title: Both Ways Is the Only Way I Want It
author: Meloy, Maile*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I am browsing through bookstore shelves, I tend to shy away from the short story collections. I'm not sure why. I know other readers who admit toWhen I am browsing through bookstore shelves, I tend to shy away from the short story collections. I'm not sure why. I know other readers who admit to doing the same thing, and they, like me, cannot say why. Maybe we just want to go on a journey, find a character or two, accept a premise, and then invest our time for the long haul. Perhaps we think if we understand a character, live a life with someone in the span of a few hundred pages, we may also understand ourselves - and others - a bit better by the end of the book. On the other hand, short stories have always seemed to me the literary equivalent of blind dates - short periods of time that require minimal emotional investment, no immediate sense of commitment, and within which you get a brief impression of someone that may or may not be correct. Like driving by lighted house windows in the dark of night. You glimpse a scene (maybe a family eating dinner together or a young married couple fighting, or a middle-aged woman caring for an elderly man), you have just enough time to feel a glimmer of attachment, maybe create a backstory, and then its on to the next lighted window. Maile Meloy's "Both Ways Is the Only Way I Want It" has changed all of that for me. From the moment I opened it, I was a fan. Meloy's writing is deceptively simple, and that is because her characters speak the way people really do. Eavesdrop on a conversation at the coffee shop or diner someday. You will see that people talk the way Meloy's characters do and not the way so many other writers would have us believe. There are many very good, very famous authors who write dialogue so unnatural I often find myself stopping mid-sentence at various points within their books to complain, "Nobody would actually say that." Meloy succeeds because you fully believe you are intruding on a real scenario, somehow overhearing it from a nearby booth or bench. I could talk about craft, because Meloy's stories are so perfectly crafted, utilizing such an economy of language and such natural markers to define her characters that you never actually see the craft in the work. It all seems so effortless. But craft to me sometimes makes people think of pretension, writers who are trying too hard to be clever or unique or poignant. Meloy sidesteps all of this, brushes off any labels, and just goes along her way. The best compliment I can give this collection is that, by the time I finished it, I remembered the first story as clearly as the last. I could have given an accurate synopsis of every story in the book to an interested party on the spot. Scenes from the lives of these characters still made me feel the weight of their choices or the heft of their indecision. Many of Meloy's observances still run through my head, striking in their minimalist honesty. One character remembers a man he disliked with the line "not even failure could make him interesting" while a devoted wife with an unfaithful husband is described "looking toward the kitchen door, like a faithful retriever with her messy hair and red nose, waiting for her master to appear." Such sparse lines give us so much information in such a small amount of space. Only one story in the collection did not work for me, a story called "Liliana," because in comparison to the others its premise seemed outlandish, a deviation from the consistent voice of the rest of the collection, like an experiment that the author chose to include. It was still very well written and had some lovely moments, but it just didn't ring true. Also, the final story, "O Tannenbaum," had a couple of implausible moments for me, as well, but those are really my only criticisms of a truly stunning piece of work, and the only flaws that brought this from a five star to a four star rating. Needless to say, Maile Meloy has given me a new-found appreciation of the short story writer, a new respect for first impressions, and a fondness for those glimpses of lighted windows in the dark. ...more
