title: Between the Bridge and the River
author: Ferguson, Craig
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was given this book as a gift by someone who knows I am a fan of the comedian's late night talk show and stand-up comedy routines. In person, FergusI was given this book as a gift by someone who knows I am a fan of the comedian's late night talk show and stand-up comedy routines. In person, Ferguson is a master of walking that tightrope between lunacy and sly intelligence. I admire that. So admittedly, I went into this novel with (perhaps unrealistic) high hopes that his fiction-writing style would emulate his comedic style. That said, I probably should not have expected the book to be funny, which I did, and which it was not. Not at all. Nor should it be. My preconceived notions about its expected humor are not Ferguson's concern, and that's fine. Yes, the book is laden with absurdity and filled with clever, sardonic comments about human nature and the state of the world, but funny it is not. I laughed out loud, exactly once, on page 300, when a particular moment struck me as amusing. On the other hand, all that the book lacks in humor it fills in with bitterness. It is an angry book, cynical and sometimes vindictive, the absurdist descriptions often used as a blunt instrument against whichever sector of the populace Ferguson deems unworthy at the time. Does this mean I did not like the book? Actually, and surprisingly, even to me, no. I ended up liking the book, despite its many flaws, the way I am able to like many people despite their flaws (and I'm quite sure the same way many people like me despite my own). Granted, I was languishing in a limbo of frustration and disappointment fully a third of the way through the book. I nearly put it down and moved on, until a Goodreads acquaintance who had read the book encouraged me to stick with it, as it would "get better." And amazingly enough, it did get better. Quite a bit better. The concept underlying the initial bitterness began to take hold and color the remaining narrative. And it's a good concept, one that has as its philosophical core a belief that all humans should concentrate on helping others and avoid the errors of perceived infallibility. A very good concept indeed. And characters I previously despised suddenly became less despicable, less unworthy of my time and commitment. The storytelling began to take hold and become far more captivating. Magic infused the plotline and new characters bolstered the sudden momentum. By the time I had finished the book I was a little sad as I felt it had finally reached its stride. Ferguson needs to practice the craft of fiction writing a bit more, as he tells us far too much that he could be showing us. There is also the hint of pretention in much of his ranting, and a sense of "look what I know that you probably don't." It is a quality I despise in writers like Umberto Eco, but one I feel quite willing to overlook in Ferguson since the premise and underlying decency of the story excused many of its problems - and because I just plain like Ferguson so much. On the plus side, several of the characters' visions and unique stories were quite inventive and compelling. Scenes involving visions of Carl Jung and Fatty Arbuckle should not have worked, but did. And the diverse storylines really converged in a meaningful way as the story unfolded. So, a book I wanted to love and ended up hating for fully a third of the way redeemed itself and became a book I reservedly liked. That said, I am glad I finished it and even felt suprisingly uplifted by the material. And I look forward to Ferguson's next offering. ...more

title: The Stranger Beside Me: Ted Bundy: The Shocking Inside Story
author: Rule, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Still the most famous - and possibly the best - of the true crime genre, featuring Ted Bundy as the poster boy for America's obsession with serial kilStill the most famous - and possibly the best - of the true crime genre, featuring Ted Bundy as the poster boy for America's obsession with serial killers. Rule's book stands out for a number of reasons. She knew Bundy, worked alongside him in a crisis center, and although she was a former policewoman with a real talent for researching sociopaths, Bundy was so intelligent, so charming, so seemingly "normal," that Rule never once suspected his darkness. Her fluid writing style and talent for conveying the facts without sensationalizing them, makes the book even more chilling in its rendering of everyday people unaware of the killer right next to them. To this day, I have a heightened awareness of the "tricks of the trade" some serial killers use to lure victims. The man with the cast who needs help carrying something, the man with crutches who keeps dropping an item, the passenger door handles removed from the inside of a car, the overly charming man who needs directions. Bundy's story is a too common one these days of the neighbor everyone liked and thought couldn't possibly have preyed upon the good intentions of unsuspecting women...until he tells the police where all the bodies are hidden (or in Bundy's case, a small fraction of the potential bodies). A must-read for anyone interested in the darkness our society can spawn. ...more

title: The Given Day        (Coughlin #1)
author: Lehane, Dennis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 1919 was one hell of a year to be living in Boston, Massachusetts. Even more so if you happened to be an Irish beat cop in the North End with terroris1919 was one hell of a year to be living in Boston, Massachusetts. Even more so if you happened to be an Irish beat cop in the North End with terrorist neighbors, a politically connected family, an undercover job infiltrating anarchist groups, and an African American buddy who happens to be running from the law for the murder of a drug dealer in Tulsa. In "The Given Day," Dennis Lehane has done more than write a big, riveting story, he has captured a time in history and made it come alive for generations of readers who might otherwise never have imagined the intense, often tragic and violent social history of their fair city. Cleverly interweaving vignettes about Babe Ruth (then a Red Sock, soon to be traded and become the cause of an 86 year curse) and some truly astonishing current events of the time, Lehane paints a very precise portrait of a country in flux, torn by inner conflict, beset by threats of Communist infiltration, racial tensions, ethnic enclaves, poverty, political corruption, and the Spanish influenza. This is my first Dennis Lehane book, though I have no idea what has kept me from him for so long. After all, as well-established and critically-acclaimed as he is nationwide, he is even more highly revered here in New England, and his familiar settings are an attractive feature of his writing for local readers. On that note, I will admit that I may be a bit biased in my regard for this book, as I found it fascinating to have Mr. Lehane tell me what the same streets I have seen many times must have been like in 1919. Hanover Street, a bustling tourist spot where gourmet Italian restaurants and sumptious bakeries now line the cobbled sidewalks, was once a sequestered enclave of dirt roads where goats and pigs roamed at will and chickens outnumbered humans as inhabitants in almost every apartment. The description of the Great Molasses Flood alone was truly astonishing. This very real occurrence in which a huge molasses tank exploded and hit Boston like a tsunami of molten sugar was something I knew about vaguely but only truly understood after the sad and shocking images Lehane detailed in this story. Moreover, the rioting caused by the Boston Police strike was described in horrific detail and gave as sobering a look at human nature as any great work of fiction ever has. I am embarrassed by all of the historical events I did not know and am indebted to this book for enlightening me in a way that will stick with me permanently and not fade like so much grade school memorization. The pervasive influence of various anarchist and workers groups during that time and the real threat they posed to the government was an eye-opener for me, as was the way law-abiding citizens were kept at the poverty level and unable to organize for betterment due to the possibility of being characterized as Bolsheviks or traitors to America. Attempts to thwart minority groups from gaining small strides in the power circles was also enlightening, though sadly not a surprise. Vignettes involving political figures of the time (from J. Edgar Hoover to then-governor Coolidge) have altered my view of them in history and the small character piece relating the intelligence and good work of James Jackson Storrow will now come to mind every time I see the turn-off for Storrow Drive.Many writers might have taken scenes from American history and used the characters as puppets to illustrate the historical events. Lehane transcends this common manipulation by giving us a tale that at its core is really about family, about friendship, and about the bonds that people form in life, whether due to - or regardless of - the external circumstances. If we did not care for the main characters in this work (namely Danny Coughlin and Luther Laurence) we would not have a story, we would have a history lesson. Danny and Luther bind us to the events because we want them to succeed, we are worried about them, we celebrate their small triumphs and care about their failures. The Irish beat cop and the African-American fugitive seem worlds apart, but they are both casualties of circumstance, men who wish to control their own destinies but have little opportunity to do so in a world controlled by others, men who wish to live contented lives with the loved ones of their choice, but who have to battle outside forces in order to do so. Yes, their story takes place in 1919, within the swirl of that social and political climate, but their core struggle, the struggle for autonomy and social justice in an unjust world is as modern as it is ancient. That's what makes "The Given Day" an emotionally powerful read as opposed to just a history lesson. ...more

title: The Monster of Florence
author: Preston, Douglas*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Some stories are created wholly by their authors, defined by concocted characters and whimsical flights of imagination, and other stories exist in theSome stories are created wholly by their authors, defined by concocted characters and whimsical flights of imagination, and other stories exist in the real world, ready-made for the taking, to be plucked from the ether and crafted into works of thought and substance by whichever authors become taken with them. If one were to hear the tale of the Monster of Florence without being first told that it was a true story, it would seem to have all of the elements of a work of fiction. Only no one would believe it. The characters would seem impossibly drawn, many of them grotesque and heinous, the plot line would seem filled with the types of corruption and miscarriages of justice that just do not occur in civilized Western society, and the resolution would seem outlandish to the point of disbelief. Welcome to Florence. I have rarely been so fascinated by a true crime case, and also rarely felt such genuine outrage toward the social climate that would allow repeated travesties of justice to occur. Because of the jaw-dropping ineptitude of the law enforcement systems of Florence and Perugia, dozens of innocent people's lives have been ruined due to this one case, (god knows how many other cases in the region have caused similar atrocities to the innocent), still more have been incarcerated for years at a time for crimes they did not commit, and power-hungry control freaks with mental delusions that border on clinical narcissism have been allowed to linger in high posts within the police force, (namely Giuttari and Mignini), making arrests based on the ravings of a crazy old psychic obsessed with satanic cults and sexual deviance. Not to mention the fact that this same ineptitude has ensured that the real killer still remains free and uncharged with any crime. Good system, that one. In the reading of this book, the first portion of it, dealing with the chilling descriptions of the serial killer at large - and journalist Mario Spezi's sensible and well documented investigation of the crimes -was fascinating to read. The killer, and his hold on the city, makes for an interesting book in and of itself. The descriptions of Florence and its storied history also create a strange juxtaposition to the crimes, giving a sense of surreal disbelief to the notion that such a beautiful region of the world, known for its scenic beauty and cultural magnificence spawned such evil. But the second portion of the book, when justice became the plaything of idiots and publicity-seekers, absolutely incensed me. That so much damage could have been done by the very people entrusted with the security of this portion of the world, that lurid, unsubstantiated claims made by delusional fools could supercede solid police procedure and adept crime scene methods, that ridiculous rants and personal vendettas overcame such modern techniques as trace evidence and DNA testing is mind-boggling. Florence (and Perugia) seem to be basing their law enforcement techniques on witch-hunting methods and convoluted logic that would have been archaic even in the 1400's. The truly sad part of it is that the same lunatic of law enforcement that railroaded so many innocents in the Monster case (and who is currently under indictment for a host of crimes related to falsification of evidence and other atrocities in that investigation) is the same lunatic beng allowed to railroad Amanda Knox in the highly publicized case in the same region. I am stunned that no one has intervened to save that poor girl and her boyfriend. The deranged inspector (Mignini) is using the same wildly inaccurate postulate about satanic ritual and sexual orgies being the motivation in that murder that he used in the unrelated Monster case (and by which he scandalized dozens of innocent residents, all of whom should sue him for defamation of character). Not to mention the fact that all of his ideas come from a psychic website run by a crazy woman that he habitually visits and whose website he quotes verbatim. Preston spends a final chapter detailing the corresponding atrocities in both cases (The Monster case and the Knox case) which makes us realize quite vividly that Amanda Knox chose the wrong Italian city within which to reside. Corrupt Perugia may never let her go even though she is surely innocent. Those who have read Preston's fiction know that he can spin a good yarn and build the momentum of the story to a chilling climax. He does the same here, only this time there is no happy ending in sight. ...more

title: The Patron Saint of Liars
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is my third Ann Patchett novel. The first one I read was her miraculous gem of a book, "Bel Canto." The second was the solid, beautifully cadenceThis is my third Ann Patchett novel. The first one I read was her miraculous gem of a book, "Bel Canto." The second was the solid, beautifully cadenced tale of a Boston family called "Run." When I discovered that "The Patron Saint of Liars" was Patchett's first novel, I assumed that the two books I named above, which came later and which I both adore, would be better crafted, more intricate, more resonant. Turns out her first novel is the one I love the best. And that's saying something. Patchett is an extraordinary writer, able to capture characters like no one else writing today. Every word her characters utter sounds authentic, every thought the reader is allowed to witness rings true. These people are so fully realized and so wholly three dimensional that by the end of the book you are certain you know them and, oddly enough, you feel they might even know you. This is not even a book you read; it is a book you feel. First, let me just say, please do not be frightened away by the subject matter. Especially the men out there. Yes, this is a book about a home for unwed mothers, the same way "The Cider House Rules" is a book about an orphanage or "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" is a book about a mental institution. It is and it isn't. No, Patchett's book is not a sweeping saga or a morality tale or a complex and didactic puzzle. It is also not "chick lit." I become very disturbed by the fact that virtually every book written by a woman runs the risk of being marginalized as some sort of fluff. If a man had written this book - or any of Patchett's books, for that matter, it would be heralded as a marvel of modern literature. And it is not that, either. It is merely a book about three people. Three brilliantly fleshed out people. And all of the other souls who come and go in the lives of those three people during the time we are allowed to spend with them. I rarely dogear books, but every now and then an image or sentence will capture a moment so perfectly, I have to remember where it was. The first time I did this was when Rose, the first character we meet, has just discovered she is pregnant and has run away from her home in California, abandoning her young husband, to go to a Catholic-run home for unwed mothers in Habit, Kentucky. As she enters a room full of pregnant girls, she describes the experience as "a gathering of distended abdomens, overinflated balloons from which small wisps of girls were attached. I felt that surely I had come to the wrong place, that whatever these girls had was not what was wrong with me." Rose, we come to discover is someone always itching to leave. She drives for no reason, collecting maps, studying routes. When conflict arises, her inner voice says, "Flee." She becomes fascinating to the reader because of the temporary nature of her presence. One never knows when she might disappear again, and always for good. The second character we meet is Son (short for Wilson), and I have to say he is now easily one of the finest characters I have ever met. The way I feel about Son is only slightly less intense than the way I feel about Atticus Finch. They were definitely cut from the same cloth, but Son would be the poor man's Atticus Finch, with a few more demons in his past. In Rose, we fear the fleeting nature of her promises, while in Son we fear for his permanence. He is the one who will always be there to hold everything together, even if it may not be what's best for him. Like Rose, he too initially fled a bad past, but when he landed in Habit, Kentucky, his legs took root, and his presence becomes as strong and comforting as an oak tree. In the dynamic between Rose and Son we learn about the way secrets shape people, what makes some people stay and what makes others run. Our third character, Cecilia, is a child growing up at a home for unwed mothers, doted on by pregnant girls and nuns, the Scout to Son's Atticus. Her life is a motif of continual loss (all the girls who have their babies and eventually leave), and her musings on the loss of a beloved person in her life strikes a chord with anyone who has ever lost someone - or feared losing someone. At one point she says, "She was lost, like a ring you swore you'd never take off but did, put it in your pocket, and the next thing you knew it was gone. The places to begin looking are as many as the breaths you took in a day. More than that. She could be anywhere, and by the time I got there, she could be someplace else again." Cecilia becomes the bridge between two disparate themes, the need to leave and the desire to stay. Her relationship with her father is so perfectly written, their daily interactions so natural, I couldn't help but feel nostalgia. At one point, when Son is injured, there are passages that describe that terrifying feeling you have when, for the first time, you realize your father is getting old, that you may have to be the one to care for him, that he may need your help and you may not know how to help him. I'm not one to cry easily at books or films, but several times the scenes were so achingly real and so mindful of those people I have known in my own life, feelings I have had exactly the way the characters experience them, that I felt a tear or two roll down my cheek. I'm not proud. I admit it. On a side note, there are several characters in the book who are nuns. As a girl who was raised as a Catholic, went to parochial school for a time, and had a great aunt who was a nun (a beautiful energetic little sprite of a woman), I can guarantee that these characterizations were absolutely perfect. I have known several nuns who resemble those in the book, and the most lovely of those, Sister Evangeline, the nun who runs the kitchen and has a gift for clairvoyance, able to predict the sex of all the babies and a few of the machinations of those in her circle, reminded me so much of my own grandmother with her sweetness and understated ways, I caught my breath at times. This is the brilliance of Ann Patchett's characters. They come from all walks of life, they inhabit places we may never have been, they live lives unlike our own, but we know them. They remind us of our own families, our own neighbors and friends, they remind us of our pasts, and our demons and our dreams and our secrets and our lies and our sacrifices. And they say to us, "What would make you run and what would make you stay? What are the secrets that haunt you and what would you do to protect the ones you love?" For me, Son captured the essence of the book's themes when he said, "People die. Terrible things happen. I know this now. You can't pick up and leave everything behind because there is too much sadness in the world and not enough places to go."...more

title: The Moviegoer
author: Percy, Walker
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Binx Bolling, Percy's protagonist in "The Moviegoer," has a lot of charming, clever things to say in his casual, conversational style that mask the trBinx Bolling, Percy's protagonist in "The Moviegoer," has a lot of charming, clever things to say in his casual, conversational style that mask the truly heart-wrenching existential musings at the core of his being. Bolling comes on the scene a likable chap with a head for stocks, a good income, a well-connected existence in upper-crust New Orleans, and a way with the ladies. Early on, we believe his habitual moviegoing is merely an escapism, a way to ward off the mundane (which it is, to an extent), until we learn more about the machinations of Mr. Bolling's inner thoughts and see that his moviegoing is a kind of religion, a Church of the Desperate Soul, within which he sees the lives of the characters as reflecting "rotatory" truths and hidden meanings important to his survival. Bolling, despite his easygoing, unserious exterior is on a search. A search for the key to overcoming the "everydayness," as he calls it. He staves off the malaise of the everydayness by making money, going to movies, and seducing his secretaries in a form of brief but serial monogamy. None of these activities seem to ward off the malaise for very long, though, and even when he is sure he should be happy, he feels the malaise of the everydayness creeping back in. He begins to believe that the only cure for the malaise is tragedy. The time he felt the most unique and alive was after having been wounded in the war. The life he has lived since then - a life full of small talk, luncheons, married friends, society functions - all of these run the risk of smothering him with their everydayness. Enter Kate, his cousin and lifelong companion with a frail psychology and a bent toward suicide. She becomes the external manifestation of his own inner fears, the person who does what he only thinks. Throughout the novel we begin to realize that her darkness lures Bolling closer to his own brink of existential despair. We begin to fear that there are only two options - someone will perish or someone will be saved. And isn't that the way of all life? Percy has hit upon some truths so obvious and defeating to the psyche that it often makes us uncomfortable to read them. Like the Myth of Sisyphus we all continually roll the boulder up the hill, heaving and panting, only to have it roll back down again and begin the task anew. No matter how many times we try, we will never complete the task, because we are all mortal. No one "wins." Bolling knows this and wonders if the living is enough to justify the life. In the end, he decides that it is, but it all could have gone the other way....more

title: Coal Black Horse
author: Olmstead, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of the darkest books I have ever read. Olmstead, utilizing the deceptively simple storyline of a boy sent by his mother to find his fatherThis is one of the darkest books I have ever read. Olmstead, utilizing the deceptively simple storyline of a boy sent by his mother to find his father and bring him home during the Civil War, has created a tale of nearly mythological proportions that explores every possible atrocity known to humankind. Along his journey, our fourteen year-old protagonist witnesses life-altering violations of human virtue, a barrage of repulsive acts and abhorrent characters that make him question everything he has ever believed about life and death. Death, in fact, permeates every sentence of this work. One cannot read this book without hard thoughts about the nature of mortality, as the work surely intends. Often, the reading of this novel was akin to watching the reels of the Nazi atrocities, eliciting the same disbelief that any human could do that to another. And yet, Olmstead's luminous prose, a strangely poetic and often unexpected use of language that mimics no other author of my acquaintance, gently pulls you along through this house of horrors and keeps you engrossed in the plight of this young innocent. So, too, does the image of the coal black horse himself, another element of the story that takes on a nearly mythical quality. The horse becomes an omniscient and powerful conscience within the tale, always observing, always aware, keenly protective, impressively strong and capable. His presence alone is a calming force for the boy - and for the reader - as we, too, are traversing this story along with our young guide and are enduring the same hollowing sense of despair. Many elements of the story reminded me of the classic Greek tragedies, so many of which are framed around a journey through war presaged by an oracle (our young protagonist's mother has the "sight" and sends her son to the battlefield after a vision she has had). At other times, I was reminded of the Divine Comedy, since the boy seems surely to be traveling through the circles of hell. In size, this is a slight book, but a weighty one in the reading of it, and although the ending gives us a small sense of some redemption for all that has happened, it never erases or glosses over the hard lessons and dark knowledge it imparts. This is a book that searches for the definition of evil, chronicles death in all its many faces, and then silently grieves for all humanity....more

review: I read this book many years ago, but still recall the gut-wrenching impact it had on me. The first part of the book is cool and dreamlike, descending I read this book many years ago, but still recall the gut-wrenching impact it had on me. The first part of the book is cool and dreamlike, descending into Freudian themes of sexuality that become almost too much to bear. There were times when I thought I might not be able to read on any further, but I did, and with each change in tone the book became more and more disturbing, and yet more and more of a revelation. The ending is hugely disturbing and incredibly powerful, and in a very rare occurrence for any book, left me heaving with sobs for nearly half an hour. I haven't cried that much since I was nine and read "Old Yeller." So, clearly not for you if you are looking for a light read, a feel-good read, a detached highbrow read. This is dark, deep, heartbreaking stuff. But, in its way, beautiful. The way a gargoyle might be. ...more

title: Eat, Pray, Love
author: Gilbert, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I didn't intend to like this book. "A woman of means and social privilege goes on a jaunt to find herself and indulge her whims and teach me a lesson I didn't intend to like this book. "A woman of means and social privilege goes on a jaunt to find herself and indulge her whims and teach me a lesson along the way about how pathetic my life is because I haven't done the same..." That's what I thought. Plus, a couple of the snobbiest women I know recommended the book to me...highly. Nope, I thought, not for me. But I was wrong. Well, no, I was right...and wrong. It IS about a woman of means in a privileged social circle who goes on a jaunt to find herself and indulge her whims after a messy divorce. And she DOES think her story will teach me a lesson about how my life, among others, is pathetic for not having done the same. But the truth is - Elizabeth Gilbert writes so well, you don't care about that. In fact, she writes so well she even redeems herself from more than occasional bouts of arrogance and showboating by being equally desperate, vulnerable, kinda kooky, and truly funny. I'm not going to kid any of the men out there by saying this isn't a "chick book." It clearly is. I think the average book-loving woman, in particular, will genuinely find Ms. Gilbert's honesty of a transcendent quality if that woman has ever been in love and heartbroken, found herself crying on a bathroom floor, found herself wanting to pack it all in and travel the world, or wanted to find a sense of peace or reverence in this unpredictable world. It wasn't lost on me that this is a book about a woman's travels after a bad split. I began this book six days ago on a plane out of Boston to take a spontaneous trip to San Antonio, my first vacation after a bad split a few months ago. I finished the book as we (my friend and I) touched down in Boston again, having come full circle with the author and her journey. The book is written in thirds. The first takes place in Italy where Gilbert throws away her structured life, learns to be free, and eats her way through the country while using pasta as a balm for grief. In India, she lives at an Ashram and learns the Yogic life, in a nearly 180 degree turn from her carefree indulgence in Italy. Finally, in Indonesia, she balances the two extremes and learns how to love again. Nice if you can do it, I know. Gilbert seemed to have an unending supply of money and a far-reaching support network. But what I got from the book, other than a very insightful, funny, and lively read, was a real sense that any of us can find transcendence, can navigate the many levels of existence in our own unique ways if we choose to live an authentic life and cultivate friendships and experiences. Life may hold sorrow and hardship, but it also houses magic and joy. Yes, it's an age-old lesson. But Gilbert tells it well enough to bring it home. Again....more

title: City of Thieves
author: Benioff, David
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are a number of reasons to love "City of Thieves" by David Benioff. The author's engaging style, for one, like the voice of a seasoned storytellThere are a number of reasons to love "City of Thieves" by David Benioff. The author's engaging style, for one, like the voice of a seasoned storyteller, weaving a vivid scene in front of you that you never question, despite the unnatural circumstances or hard-to-believe scenarios. The graphic history of WWII Russia, for another, rendered in heartbreaking detail through vignettes that offer glimpses into the suffering and tenacity of the populace during the siege. Additionally, there is the excellent pacing of the novel, always moving effortlessly through the horrors and unexpected turns of war, while offering just enough comic relief to keep it bearable and endearing. But the main reason to love "City of Thieves" is the relationship between its two main characters, Lev and Kolya, the thief and the deserter, (though neither deserves the label with which he has been saddled, since Lev is a one-time thief having taken a knife from a dead German invader and Kolya is an accidental deserter who never meant to leave his unit for good). The pair become bound in an unexpected mission - to somehow find and deliver, in just a few days, a dozen eggs to a Russian general to be used to bake a cake for his daughter's upcoming wedding. If they can find this rare commodity in a war-torn Russia in which the people are starving and have been known to eat glue from the binding of library books - their lives will be spared. This unusual premise is the foundation for what, at its heart, is really a buddy movie masquerading as a novel, an almost visual manifestation of two mismatched characters who form a bond of real admiration and affection despite their differences and disparate backgrounds. Lev is the young teenager, a virgin and master chess player hiding his literary and Jewish heritage, while Kolya is the charming and worldly wise twenty-something, a handsome army enlistee who has dreams of being a famous novelist and has a female admirer in every town. The story of their developing friendship is the heart and soul of the story and the reason this novel is more than just an interesting read, but a truly memorable one. Not everything in the novel is believable, and the ending bothered me quite a bit, because even though I knew it was going to happen and fully expected it, the timing came so late in the book that it almost felt like an unnecessary cheap shot, like something that should have happened earlier or not at all. By then, I didn't need the package to be wrapped up nearly as tightly or with such stylistic precision. It all felt a little false. That said, I was still completely enthralled throughout the entire book, I was fully able to suspend disbelief and accept all of the outlandish scenarios (until twenty or so pages before the book's end), and I admit I even fell a little bit in love with the brash, dashing Kolya and his charm and bravado. I have no idea who could capture that big personality on-screen, but some smart filmmaker better start looking for someone who can - because, after all, this is really a buddy movie at heart....more

title: The Terror
author: Simmons, Dan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was tentative about starting this book, because a "horror" novel based on the true voyage of the Franklin Expedition had the potential to be, if notI was tentative about starting this book, because a "horror" novel based on the true voyage of the Franklin Expedition had the potential to be, if not downright awful, at the very least immensely silly, and at 900 plus pages that would be quite the investment of time for a book that might ultimately disappoint on a grand scale. With that said, I am happy to report that this is one of the best books I have ever read. Granted, it doesn't hurt if you are fascinated with the lore of those explorers who searched for the Northwest Passage (as I am). It also doesn't hurt if you are willing to suspend disbelief the teeniest bit in order to make the leaps of imaginative storytelling our author makes. Nonetheless, this obviously well-researched novel is a fantastic character study that posits the probable outcomes for each man aboard the two vessels (Terror and Erebus) as they became trapped in the ice off of King William Sound and lost forever. Without giving too much away, the book's "monster" adds complexity to a novel that would stand as great fiction even without its appearance, in that it can be viewed quite literally as a monster or in a solely metaphorical way, (much like Danielewski's "House of Leaves") according to each reader. That, and the brilliant storytelling style of the author, help to transcend this book from "horror" novel to unforgettable piece of fiction. When I neared the end of the book, I started to read more slowly, as I knew it would be like saying goodbye to a friend once I reached the end. I will definitely be reading more books by this author in the near future. ...more

title: The Devil in the White City
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fascinating look at two sides of Chicago in the late 1800's - the White City of the World's Fair (aka the Columbian Exposition) and the Black City of Fascinating look at two sides of Chicago in the late 1800's - the White City of the World's Fair (aka the Columbian Exposition) and the Black City of crime, poverty, the slaughterhouse stench and the purely evil figure of H.H. Holmes, Chicago's Jack the Ripper, who took advantage of the fair to find young single female victims to kill. When I first picked up this book to read, I thought the story of the hideous Mr.Holmes would be the more interesting of the two plots. I was wrong. The building of the fair was the far more interesting plot, in sheer size and scale often overwhelming the reaches of my imagination. So many amazing achievements came to light at the fair, and it truly is an event that changed the world forever. Breakthroughs in electricity, construction, design, science and technology, commercial products, even cultural diversity blossomed in Chicago during this small window of time. I found myself mesmerized by the true story of a group of architects (!) on a seemingly impossible mission. Yes, this story easily could have been as dry as a textbook in another author's hands, but Larson brings the details to life and truly fleshes out these fantastic characters. The glimpse into Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show alone was worth the price of admission. There were passages that went on a bit too long, perhaps (particularly as regards the lanscape architecture of the famous Frederick Law Olmstead), but otherwise this is a book that both captured my attention and taught me a great deal about a piece of history about which I knew embarrassingly little. ...more

title: Great Expectations
author: Dickens, Charles
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: C'mon, how can you not give it five stars? It's Dickens at the height of his talent. Every young adult should have to read this book at some point, ifC'mon, how can you not give it five stars? It's Dickens at the height of his talent. Every young adult should have to read this book at some point, if only to get a perspective on life's priorities and where true success really resides. Pip's desire for wealth and status radiates from his wish not to be thought common in the eyes of his beloved and her society, undeserving as they may be of his esteem. When he finally sees the error of his ways and the way he has turned his back on the people who were his true source of happiness, it is a hard-earned lesson, but an enlightening one, and one he learns in time to keep himself from being doomed by his own "great expectations." There is no pat happy endng here, no neat little wrap-up. It is a story like any life story, full of small triumphs and defeats and larger tragedies, mistakes, regrets, and unexpected joy. The characters are unforgettable - who could ever forget the withering crone, Miss Havisham, who has molded the haughty Estella to be the source of her own revenge upon mankind; the misguided Pip, in love with the wrong girl and thrown into unexpected wealth by a shadowy benefactor; the salt of the earth soul Joe Gargery, unable to hold a grudge or see the bad side of others - and the list goes on and on. Dickens' vivid portrait of London in this era, his completely enthralling characters and his wry humor make his work a glorious addiction....more

review: Reposting this : RIP Jim Carroll, poet, punk rocker, inspiration. Thank you for expanding the boundaries of my mind at an early age. May all of Reposting this : RIP Jim Carroll, poet, punk rocker, inspiration. Thank you for expanding the boundaries of my mind at an early age. May all of the other "People Who Died" be there to greet you. I read this book when I was twelve years old. An aunt gave me a tattered copy of it, knowing I liked poetry, but not knowing that Jim Carroll's poetry might change the chemistry of my brain cells forever. At twelve, I found it strange and dangerous. By the time I was seventeen, I had researched the time of this poetry: Warhol, Edie Sedgwick, the Velvet Underground and all of the NYC crowd who longed to be living works of art. Suddenly, the life of a small Catholic junkie became the voice of the city itself, and I saw the urban brilliance of it in every stark line. I have kept the same tattered copy close to me all of these years, and it still feels like a crazy old friend you could never abandon, no matter how much money he needed to borrow or how many nights he needed to sleep on your couch. You still love to see him at the door....more

review: A brilliantly realized book about high school football in a part of Texas that might be one of the poorest, most desolate areas in all of America. If A brilliantly realized book about high school football in a part of Texas that might be one of the poorest, most desolate areas in all of America. If you are not from that area, you may not understand the obsession and life-or-death nature of the game down there, but pass through some day and you will understand why more people attend those games than attend most pro sports facilities on any given Sunday. Because every Friday night some kid in Texas might just crawl out of that hole and make it to a better life. And for the folks who watch, they can root for their kids, or live vicariously through them, or for one night only swell with pride over the only thing that gives them pride. For one night a week, for one season a year, the world is bathed in light, and the dark Texas night is not the only place to find a star....more

I read this book several years ago (and even remember reading a huge chunk of it in the laundromat and another huge chunk of it outside the same laundromat, which had closed up but I could not stop reading), because it was pretty much surgically attached to my hand the entire time. Berendt brought these eccentrics to life in a way that made the entire culture mesmerizing and almost endearing. A really unfortunate film was subsequently made of the book and was a complete and utter failure in its attempt to grasp what Berendt knew early on. This is not a story about people, not a film about secrets or oddities, voodoo or murder. This is a love story between the author and the town of Savannah, herself, a town that ultimately becomes the most important character in the book, and Berendt fleshes it out in a way that still leaves me feeling like I have been there when, in fact, I have not. It should have made for a riveting story, full of twists and turns, savory Cold war nuggets and revealing baseball lore. And in the hands of another author, perhaps it would have. Wordy, barren of excitement, the account strips down even the most interesting facts of Berg's life to their most mundane parts. review: This is a perfect little capsule of a book. Patchett's prose is so effortless, the cadence so gorgeous, the dialogue so natural, it is like entering aThis is a perfect little capsule of a book. Patchett's prose is so effortless, the cadence so gorgeous, the dialogue so natural, it is like entering a story rather than reading it. I have read a few s that bemoaned the supposed contrivances of the plot or felt the characters were obvious "types." With all due respect, I thought the characters were anything but, and I understand that disturbingly unrealistic contrivances deter from a book, but necessary contrivances occur in virtually every book known to humankind, not to mention most actual lives. This book was rooted firmly in the latter category for me. I adored this book. Days later, I still miss the characters (something I don't think I would be doing, if they were, in fact, "types" rather than fully developed people). I do ask myself if I would have loved this book as much if it had not been so familiar to me. It takes place in Boston (I am from the area); the core family is rooted in the Irish American Catholic Democratic traditions (I am an Irish American Democrat who was raised in the Catholic tradition). So many people and places resonate with me and populate my world. I can say these people are not types because I know them, they inhabit my world, and Patchett captured them perfectly. I thought this book took on matters of race and social class in a way that brought them to a personal level, rendering them the everyday matters of a family, as they so often are. I appreciated the nuances of the characters living those lives as much as the social climate within which they exist. Those who have read Patchett's earlier masterpiece "Bel Canto" may be inclined to shrug this book off because at first glance it seems a smaller, more personal book, with less expansive themes and a less global feel. I would suggest that no one make the mistake of thinking that because this book is crafted in a more minimal style and revolves around one family in one time period that it is a "smaller" book. The themes are just as relevant, the scope just as all-encompassing. Patchett does what the best poets do. She takes the specific and makes it universal. ...more

title: An Arsonist's Guide to Writers' Homes in New England
author: Clarke, Brock
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a really fun read without being a frivolous read. In fact, the author takes on a myriad of dark themes, but in the voice of his main charThis book is a really fun read without being a frivolous read. In fact, the author takes on a myriad of dark themes, but in the voice of his main character, Sam Pulsifer, has a way of making even the most atrocious goings-on seem hilariously funny. Sam is a self-confessed bumbler, habitual liar, and accidental arsonist, and yet in the hands of Brock Clarke, somehow none of that seems unusual. And believe me, that's not the half of the unusual aspects of this book and its characters. Like Irving or Vonnegut or Richard Russo at his most inventive, never once do we question the believability of any of Clarke's characters or the wacky shenanigans that occur in these pages. And that's doubly interesting, because much of the book has to do with authors and their characters, and a continual debate about which ones seem more like "real people." For me, this book was a big, raucous, crazy, poignant, shocking, lovable atrocity that you miss the second it's over. ...more

title: House of Leaves
author: Danielewski, Mark Z.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are only two words to describe this book: Pure Genius. I worried initially how a book with this conceptual framework and storyline could maintaiThere are only two words to describe this book: Pure Genius. I worried initially how a book with this conceptual framework and storyline could maintain its brilliance over the span of a few hundred pages, without devolving into novelty or pretention. Not only does Danielewski maintain its brilliance, but with each new page he expands upon it, making the underlying themes darker (or occasionally lighter) and always more richly expressed. If anyone deigns to call this a horror novel, then it is the quintessential horror novel, exploring every angle of the primal horror of mortality and how each being has his or her own unique survival instinct in the face of that inevitable void. One er called this book "Stephen King meets Nabokov," which is true in its way. If I were to find an analogy in that framework, I would call it "Shirley Jackson meets James Joyce." Jackson could make even a happy day seem ominous in the description of the architecture housing her characters: lines that do not quite meet up, angles that seem impossible in pure geometry, floors that do not seem even, ceilings that hang too low. Take that subtle and continual foreboding and match it up with the expansive themes and experimental brilliance of Joyce and you may be looking at their twisted little lovechild. You will decide for yourself what "the house" in this novel means for you...and what the architecture of your own house may reveal. ...more

review: I love Dean Koontz, but this is not his best book. That said, it is still an absorbing read and a worthwhile one. Koontz is always interesting in thatI love Dean Koontz, but this is not his best book. That said, it is still an absorbing read and a worthwhile one. Koontz is always interesting in that he can paint the darkest of the dark when it comes to villains - truly disturbing people with genuinely bone-chilling behaviors - and yet he radiates an almost ethereal belief in goodness that permeates all of his books. He continues his love affair with golden retrievers in this work, and ably works his magic in that regard, as his chief canine character here is fleshed out as well as any human character. I think Koontz will always suffer from the fact that his one true masterpiece ("Watchers," of course) has already been written and other works, though commendable, will never equal it. That said, if you want a chilling (and often, heartwarming and thought-provoking) light horror to curl up with on a rainy fall evening - and particularly, if you love dogs - this is the book for you....more

title: The Prince of Tides
author: Conroy, Pat
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It has been awhile since I read this great book, but at the time, many years ago, a friend and I were sharing a copy and reading it in turns. As we goIt has been awhile since I read this great book, but at the time, many years ago, a friend and I were sharing a copy and reading it in turns. As we got drawn further and further into its pages, we would literally sit at each other's feet waiting for the next chapter to be finished in order to pass it between us. The book was so intense and yet flowed so beautifully, with its dark family secrets and memorably flawed characters and innate sense of place. It became an addiction. When the movie came out, I was greatly disappointed with the way it was made an overblown homage to one character at the expense of several others. The most captivating character in the book, in fact, (the siblings' brother Luke), is removed completely. It is unusual for me to read a book about a family this dysfunctional and this fraught with damaging memories - and yet to remember it so fondly and its characters with so much tender regard. I attribute much of that to the skill of Pat Conroy. He understands human flaws so well and describes them with such insight that even his villains are hard to hate. And he captures the South with both the love and disdain of a true native son. And by the way, this is no chick book. The roommate was a male (a rugged one, at that) and his  would look a lot like this one. :)...more

title: In the Cut
author: Moore, Susanna
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A book as gorgeously crafted as it is tremendously disturbing. This teacher with a dark side tells us right from the start that she is doing somethingA book as gorgeously crafted as it is tremendously disturbing. This teacher with a dark side tells us right from the start that she is doing something she knows she should not do and that her story will deal with irony and realism. Knowing that, we let her lead us into a brutal but tempting world of ironic twists and realistic hard edges that surround every new encounter or ominous remark, and every strangely erotic act or brush with kink. And through it all she expounds so brilliantly on literature and the written word that the life she leads becomes tied to the page in a way that makes her actions indistinguishable from the way they are described. The narrator becomes her own protagonist. I won't give away the ending but I will say that it utilizes one of the most effective literary devices I have ever encountered. The book haunted me long after I had read it, and as disturbing as it is, I have reread it several times since. Susanna Moore's voice is unlike that of any other woman writing today. There seems to be no dark corner she is afraid to explore, and often, illuminate....more

title: The Grizzly Maze: Timothy Treadwell's Fatal Obsession with Alaskan Bears
author: Jans, Nick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For reasons I have yet to pinpoint, I am fascinated with Treadwell. His life, his personality, the apparent dichotomy within him, the personal TreadweFor reasons I have yet to pinpoint, I am fascinated with Treadwell. His life, his personality, the apparent dichotomy within him, the personal Treadwell, the private Treadwell and the way he reinvented himself. Oh yeah, and and all of those BEARS. With zero experience, zero training, and zero education in the field, he decided it was his destiny to spend months every year living in a tent amidst grizzly bears, studying them, protecting them, and taking some of the most incredible footage ever shot. That he was eventually eaten by one is not a huge surprise. That he managed to live among them for thirteen years, however, is a gargantuan surprise. The kind of thing that makes it hard for even his staunchest critics to explain. And that, I feel, is why both the author and people like me keep going back to his story, looking at it from every angle, trying to dissect it and apply meaning where perhaps none is deserved. Some people are bigger than life, and like him or not, Treadwell was one of those people. A very well-written book about Treadwell and others who choose to lead unique lives in places where nature can be both beautiful and brutal. ...more

All of Gould's books on natural history and the social and biological sciences are fascinating, but this work was groundbreaking, because it spoke to the inherent ethnocentric bias that insidiously altered our understanding of race differences through the "mismeasure" of human remains. Brilliant, eye-opening, and a must read not only for all who work and study in these fields but for everyone else, as well. ...more

title: Bel Canto
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a small miracle of a book. How a book about a hostage situation in a South American country can be so tender and filled with such marvels of hThis is a small miracle of a book. How a book about a hostage situation in a South American country can be so tender and filled with such marvels of human observation is still a surprise to me. The hostages, who consist of a famous American opera singer, a powerful Japanese businessman, and a host of attendees from various countries who speak diverse languages, all come together (through a four and a half month stalemate with the government) to form a small, self-sustaining, and eventually beneficial unit. There is one translator who acts as a conduit of verbal communication between the various hostages, but otherwise they are left to their own devices to coexist with any understanding of each other, and the book shows us the many forms of communication that can exist between people, as well as the many words that can hold different meanings for each speaker. Love is one of these words; happiness is another. There are so many different ways in which we love and so many diverse scenarios that can represent true happiness. The hostages become aware of this in ways they never imagined. They begin to form a bond with their captors, and through it all the group shares the unifying power of music as a central theme of the story. The opera singer becomes almost a metaphor in and of herself for the best part of the human spirit. Juxtaposed against the violence of society and the social inequalities of the world at large, we view a microcosm of that world and see the utopia possible when a group comes together in acceptance. Of course, utopia is a conceptual entity and we know as we read this story that eventually the world will be showing up at the door to try to knock that utopia down, but I, for one, kept stubbornly ignoring that fact, the way the hostages do, happy in my self-delusion as they were in theirs. And ultimately, this book requires that we decide for ourselves whether or not we know what love is, whether or not we know the meaning of happiness, do we believe in the goodness of people and embrace all that is good in the human spirit, do we accept the differences of others, and is there truly hope for us all. ...more

title: State of Fear
author: Crichton, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: [NOTE: This  was written before Mr. Crichton's untimely death, and although I still stand by my , I feel compelled to mention that there a[NOTE: This  was written before Mr. Crichton's untimely death, and although I still stand by my , I feel compelled to mention that there are a number of Mr. Crichton's books that I have not only enjoyed, but truly loved - books that awakened my imagination and enlightened me. That is why I feel badly that the harsh  below is the one that stands here on Goodreads as a testament to my feelings about his work. Truly, it is only an assessment of this ONE work, a book I consider an aberration from the other gems he has written.]Truly one of the worst books I have ever read. This book started with a great deal of promise. A series of vivid occurrences of espionage linked to scientific pursuits in exotic locales. Eco-terrorism, shady business dealings and a cast of potentially interesting characters. And then...it all self-destructed into a ludicrous mess that was not only idiotic in its pacing and plot contrivances but preachy and annoying, with characters of such brutish ignorance being lectured to by such emotionally-void snobs that you end up not liking anyone and just wishing this interminable muddle would end. As a reader who has been a fan of Crichton for several years, I have to say that it is the type of book that made me wonder how far he has sunk in his now-endless endeavor to get another book to the screen. I imagine him writing these ridiculous action scenes as if he is some pseudo-Spielberg lining up the shot and working the formula with just the right John Williams-type music in the background. In his quest to achieve what he mistakes as a riveting nailbiter, Crichton even has one character endure an escape from an Antarctic crevasse, an escape from eco-terrorist gunmen, an escape from a vehicle in a flash flood seconds before it crashes down a waterfall, an escape from a potentially fatal rare mini-octopus bite, an escape from cannibals, and an escape from a series of tidal waves...all in the course of a few days! And this is a character that in any realistic scenario would not have been asked to come along on any of the specialized military jaunts that produce these outcomes in the first place. For some reason, instead of utilizing a force of well-trained military agents to carry out the attack operations necessary to combat the highly-organized evil villains in the book, Crichton believes the uber-genius special agent in his book would use a reluctant young trial attorney, a secretary, an actor, and the agent's untrained niece to do the lion's share of the work needed to disable sophisticated machinery, track down veteran assassins, utilize a range of munitions and infiltrate areas that the Delta Force would find too challenging. I have rarely been so disappointed in a book. If Crichton were to walk into the room after I had finished it, I may have slapped him. And don't even get me started on the haughty pompous tone of the book and its one-sided caricatures meant to represent ecological viewpoints. I think from now on, I will just reread an early Crichton book if I get the urge to try a new one from him. He used to take brilliant scientific notions and utilize them in well-conceived stories that had some depth and an understanding of the inner life of a character. Now, he writes screenplays full of fools in such overblown action scenes, they would make Michael Bay blush. ...more
